content:
Posted: April 3, 2013
												If you look from the point of this not being a game and infact being a story then it is beautiful. The way Telltale managed to tell the story while giving you some involvemnet was captivating, true your choices don't really account for much (if someones gonna die, you can't save them) but still with each decision you will make different characters respond to you in different ways.The graphics, while not amazing for a game released in 2012, are beautiful, the comic-booky look works really well with the story feeling of the game. Voice acting is astounding and the music helps to keep the atmosphere. It is a little glitchy/buggy, but hardly enough for you to take notice of given then compelling side of the story telling.The characters are good, each with their own history. You can almost get to know these people, feel emotion with them as if you were actually Lee, it is submersive and it does this aspect well. You start the game in a police car on your way to jail,the car then hits a 'walker' and crashes its way off the road into a small wooded area. You have escaped jail, you are given a second chance at life, well too bad that second chance just happens to fall at the begining of a zombie apoc. You encounter a small child and take her under your wing, protecting her as if she was your own child, trying to always look out for her, do your best for her, ultimately ensuring her safety above your own. Travelling from place to place with the survivors you round up on your journey eventually endind up in the city of Savannah, this is where things got complicated for me, the ending. It is lacking, the last chapter and the things that happen in it just made me scream WTF, the actions of a certain person not justified fully enough to account for the things they are trying to do. It is a poor ending and after being so submerged in the rest of the game this kinda ruined it for me slightly, although I still enjoyed the game and the final, final, final bit was great.Overall it is really a point and click adventure/visual movie with minimal input and not infact a 'game', but it made me feel emotion and it kept me entertained for 16 hours, I'd play through again too, just to make different choices, even though I know they won't affect the overall game.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Lots of nice situations, often times without the option you would want.. but what do you expect - and it all goes down alright for the sake of story.The game is quite good, quite lengthy and the final chapter quite impressed me. I enjoyed it as a whole and I recall a lot of it despite playing the 5 seasons over approximately 18 months.There are some great characters and some great situations. The game holds your hand a lot, but it's mainly a story-telling experience anyway - the only issue I had with the gameplay was the lengthy *actions* that can trigger if I clicked something twice, which you might do if you think that your character (Lee) might have the same insight you have (not often the case). Nonetheless, the game is fun and I recommend you play it, though probably picked up on a good sale tbh.My biggest peeve was that a good number of episodes were driven by character interactions between your group, but the game never presented me with the option I wanted (namely who I should be accusing). I found it weird as much of the game was about managing relationships AND ACCUSATIONS, but the time that I most wanted to accuse somebody of the poison that saw massive change (and the loss of the single group member that I wanted to keep), there was no option to remove the single most destructive group member (my opinion for a while before that happened, and ultimately proven by the end of the game to be your *worst* team member).I hope Telltale Games grow a pair and tell their funding groups that they want to make a more ambitious game. From what I've heard, they may already have done so.

												I played this game many moon ago when it released on 360 and recently purchased it on STEAM to play through once again. It is one of my personal favorite games. While having zombies in it, the fun doesnt come from cracking their heads (although there is plenty of it). The game is based around the relationships and interactions you have with the NPCs through the decisions you make during tough situations. You will both make and burn bridges with characters. You only hope you didnt side with the guy that gets killed ten minutes later and are stuck dealing with the guy you sided against for rest the game. As you will find if you play the game, the living can be much more dangerous than the dead. 12-15 Hours (more if you buy "400 days" episode) playthrough depending on how much stuff you examine. Its a great game, with an amazing story (that your choices help write), that is very different from other "Zombie" titles out there!

												The Walking Dead: The Game : แบบจำลองการเอาตัวรอดจาก ซอมบี้(10/10 A++++)ดีมากและพีคมาก สิ่งหนึ่งที่ทำให้เกมนี้ดีได้ดีคือ สามารถทำให้เราติดตามกับเนื้อเรื่องของเกมได้ดี อาจจะเป็นเพราะการทำในรูปแบบเป็นตอนๆ ทำให้เรารู้สึกเหมือนทีวีซีรี่ย์ คอยติดตามตั้งแต่ต้นจบจนโดยไม่พักเลยอีกสิ่งหนึ่งที่ชอบคือการฆ่าตัวละครหลักๆของเราที่เราคอยเชียร์ มันทำให้เรารู้สึกติดกับเนื้อหาของเกมว่าใครจะเป็นรายต่อไป (นั้นหละวิธีทางของ GOT) ระบบการเล่น: การเล่นจะเป็นแบบตัดสินใจ ทุกอย่างที่้เราทำมันส่งผลกับตัวละครอื่นๆกับเหตุในอนาคต เช่นถ้าเราโกหกแล้วตอบหลังจากนั้นเราตอบไม่ตรงกับที่โกหก เขาจะจับผิดได้ จากนี้ยังมีแอคชั่นในกดในลุ้นอยู่บ่อยๆ ซึ่งบอกเลยถ้าไม่เล่นแบบสัญลักษณ์บอก ผมคงได้ตายหลายรอบอยู่ภาพ: เกมนี้ออกหลัง Borderlands ภาคแรก ผมรู้กสึกว่าการออกแบบของเกมนี้ใน ss1 มันยังดูแข็งๆอยู้ถ้าเทียบกับ Borderlands ที่ภาพมันคล้ายๆกันนะ แล้วถ้าลองสังเกตดีๆจะเห็นว่าฉากพวกฝูงซอบบี้ แม่งมีขยับๆอยู่7-8  ตัวที่เหลือแม่งเป็นวอลเปเปอร์แข็งๆที่เห็นชัดมากข้อเสีย : -ผมเล่นเกมนี้ปี2015 แต่มันยังมีบางอย่างให้เห็นอยู่เช่น ตัวละครทะลุฉาก-ตัวเลือกในการตอบ ไม่ได้แสดงอารมณ์ที่แน่ชัด ทำให้การตอบของเราจากความหมายหนึ่งไปอีกความหมายหนึ่ง-ตัวเลือกการตอบกับเนื้อหาของเกมเรียงเป็นแนวตรงและเดาได้ เช่น ถ้าอยากตอบแบบดีเลือก อันแรก ถ้าอยากเชี้ยตอบอันสุดท้าย หลังๆดีหน่อยมีการสลับบางสรุป: ผมว่ามันดีมากเลยเสียดายที่ไม่ได้ซื้อตอนออกใหม่ อยากมีความรู้สึกแบบ รอตอนต่อไปอย่างใจจดใจจ่อมาก ถึงจะบอกว่าการตัดสินใจมีผลแต่เอาเข้าจริงมันก็ไม่มีผลอะไรมากนัก เพราะยังไงเนื้อเรื่องมันก็ยังเป็นเส้นตรง

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2013
												As a fan of the first season of the show, I really wanted this game to work. It was recommended to me as a great story driven game with deep charcters. And it is exactly that, but more!Not really enjoying this genre - I was beyond pleasantly suprised with the game! It made me reconsider my thoughts on the genre as a whole.The word as we all know it has ended. Zombie craziness has ensued. You are Lee, you are riding in the back of a police car when the game begins. You'll find a small child and become responsible for her and here is where the similarities between your playthrough and mine will end!Your game will be shaped by the choices you make, or don't make, the things you say, or don't say and the people you save, or don't...The game has an understandably small cast, because, you know, the world has ended.The charcters you encounter are well written and believable. Resulting in sometimes agonising choices that need to be made. I found myself really caring about the charcters and wanting to do what's best for them all. This is a credit to the game designers who have done an outstanding job with designing them .As Lee you will have limited time to read through the choices and shape the game you want to play. This game will demand a reply if only to find out what would have happened if you'd said something different at that critical moment!Decisions I made in the first episode are coming back to haunt me even now, in the middle of episode 4!Although there are no real brain crushing puzzels to be found, there are a few basic ones to be solved and that's fine.The puzzles never get too trying or boring and are broken up very nicely by bludgeoning, slashing, stabbing and a general variety of very satisfying zombie killsA great introduction to the genre and a great game in general too!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												As a standalone game, The Walking Dead is excellent. I specifically say standalone, as there is a sequel, and it's very obvious from the ending of the first one that there was more story left to tell. Unfortunately, the sequel shames the greatness of the first game. So, if you're able to enjoy the game on its own merits, despite the emptiness from the story not being continued after the final episode, I would definitely recommend it.The Walking Dead is in many ways a story first, then a game. The main interactivty comes in with adjusting the way the story goes to your liking. The player character, Lee, can be as compassionate, morally grey, or obnoxious as you like, despite the presence of his moral compass so to speak, the young girl Clementine, whose parents have been lost to the zombie apocalypse. Granted, Lee will still show he cares a great deal for Clementine even if you make him a complete jerk, but you can still play him in a way that'd make it seem like poor Clementine would be better off without him. If you try to play the compassionate route, all the moral dilemmas that the zombie apocalypse throws at you may make you realise that doing the right thing isn't always so clear!It should be made clear, this is a story that revolves around the characters, as does the interactivty. Do not expect major branching, or even really much branching at all, in the plot. But do expect some variety in how long certain characters stick around and how they act towards Lee depending on what you have him say and do. Chances are, you're going to come out of this game wondering just how confident you are in your own morals.The biggest flaw of the game as it stands on its own is by far the lack of bug removal. You probably won't run into anything major playing through it once, but if you replay it, which isn't exactly an odd choice when I've played through it about 8 times and still haven't seen everything, you become more likely to have your save messed up, or the cursor refusing to go all the way to the right of the screen, and so on. On a technical level it's appalling how little Telltale cared.If you can get past the fact it doesn't really feel like a complete story due to the lack of a good second season, the fact your choices only affect characters to a degree, and the horde of bugs, this is a good game. Hell, before the second season really went to crap during its final two episodes, I barely had a bad thing to say about this game, the main gripe really is that its sequel is so bad. If you want an extremely immersive, gripping, emotional interactive story, this may be a good place to look!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2012
												I wrote a recommendation when this game first came out. On the first 5 minutes, I was hooked, and I said it was a 'great game.' However, after playing to the very end, I now understand the previous recommendation did not do this game the justice it deserves. It did not even come close.This game was brilliant. I will not reveal what happens, but the game's ending is the most heart-wrenching video game moment I have ever seen. The graphics may not be that of a 2012 game, but the pure excellence of this game is worth more than all the graphics in the world. Never have I seen a game that gives you a chance to create such a strong bond with all the characters that you meet, even the ones that didn't particularly like you. Throughout the entire story, I was on the edge of my seat, even after the last credit rolled off the screen. With astonishing writing, compelling characters, a heart-wrenching ending, and a strong emotional consistency, this game is - without a doubt - THE best game of 2012.Fellow gamers, whether you like zombie games or not, hear me out: play this game.You will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												Waaay better than the TV Show and probably the first Telltale Game I actually enjoyed. I didn't like how Telltale games became so simplified that they're essentially just one long cutscene that asks you to push a few buttons from time to time, because I like a little more interactivity in my adventures. I also don't usually believe in license games for shows or movies. But I finally chose to ignore that and give them another try and treat this like something I might watch on TV - And I'm glad that I did! Gameplay is hardly worth mentioning, it's super easy and all as mentioned. But the story is one of the finest I ever got to play, creating a real emotional investment that reminded me a little of "To the Moon". There's lots of drama, flavored after the show of course but a lot more tolerable because there's no lame fillers / much smaller fillers than in the show and you get to be able to participate yourself, even if it is barely more than an Illusion of choice. Each episode was pretty nice and satisfying. There's also always some twists to keep things interesting so you don't always know what to expect. Choices don't matter as much as they want you to believe so I dunno about Replay value, but I wouldn't wanna miss this for sure. Get it for the cute little Clementine alone! :D

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												The Walking Dead is an interesting visual novel/point and click type of game. When I first went into it I thought it was about  talking to my group and trying to change their fates through our interactions. I was horribly disappointing to realize no matter what you do or what you say, the outcome is always the same. There is a huge amount of "illusion of choice" There is one point in the game where you have to choose between saving this guy or saving this girl. When you save one, the other dies and the story goes in a different direction and encourages replaying the game! Right? Wrong. Not twenty minutes later, the person you save dies anyways. In the end no matter your choice, both end up dead. There was no choice! This pattern continued through the whole game, I'd be promoted with a choice and the inevitable would eventually happen. I finished the game with a bad taste in my mouth. That is until I saw a discussion online about Kenny, one of the characters. The thread started off with someone saying how awesome Kenny was.He always had your back, was friendly, sacrificed himself, he was cool. I agreed. However most people in the thread said he was a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥! I was completely in disagreement! They were even listing quotes he NEVER said in the game! That was when it hit me. The events of the game are unchangeable but the characters and the way they interact with you is completely different for each player depending on your choices. Kenny was a nice guy in my game but a jerk in many other people's games. It made discussion about the game a ton of fun since everyone's experience with each character was completely different. Some characters tell some players things other players will never hear them say.Sure the events were out of your control but that kind of game would be a little high budget for Telltale, so I think what they pulled off was pretty well done all things considered. My advice is do NOT go into the game with the thought that you can change the outcome of certain character's gruesome fates, but you can change their personalities, and compare the differences and similarities between your characters and your friend's characters' personalities. Your "best bro" in your game could be your friend's biggest rival or worst enemy!

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												I don't have a daughter, but if I did I would probably hate her because she wasn't Clem.  The decisions I made in this game weren't about what serves my interests best, or the interests of the group, but on what a bunch of electrical pulses communicating in a binary language in the form of a young girl would think of me.  More or an interactive story than a game - there aren't much in the way of mechanics - but it's the story, and vitally, the tough choices you have to make that keep you gripped and progressing forward.  Your young companion is not just someone you have to protect, but it is someone you have to justify your choices to, and the game makes sure that this is something that matters.Very easily the best 'Walking Dead' story, and an excellent example of how gaming - as loosely as the term can be applied to this game - can be used to help convey emotion which other mediums can often fall flat of due to their passive nature.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Let's begin by saying that The Walking Dead isn't so much a game as an interactive "choose your own adventure" book. There are a few action sequences but for the most part you are interacting with the different characters you meet and making decisions about what you should do at different decision points. These decisions have repercussions on what happens in the story.As a game it isn't very entertaining to be honest. As a story it is both bleak and potentially inspiring depending on how you look at it. Had I paid full list price I would have been greatly disappointed in both the game play and the length of the game. However, on steep sale this isn't a bad way to spend 8-10 hours or so. Just don't go into it expecting a happy ending or really even closure to the story as this is "Season 1" of a longer story arc.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2013
												Telltale's The Walking Dead is based on the canon of the hit TV Show and graphic novel series.  It is a point-and-click adventure game with quicktime elements - and it's a very good one.  The narrative, storytelling, and characterization is top notch and if one can refer to a story as "heavy" this game is more like having a pickup truck sitting on your chest.  It's a prime example of interactive storytelling and is an excellent model of how you can use the gaming medium to convey a story to an audience - even the camera angles it utilizes were wonderful, from staring at your reflection in a puddle as you beat someone's brain in to adding tension by having a skewed angle while you climb a ladder.  The game did have some pitfalls that comes with the point-and-click genre that it didn't avoicd unfortunately - repeatedly viewing things instead of acting on them/with them, repeating dialogue options accidentally without the ability to skip them, a few character and graphics glitches (I vividly remember speaking to an invisible Vernon and Kat cradling an invisible Duck in her arms) but besides a 4th wall breaking comic intervention these small negatives don't detract too much from the story as a whole.  The plot is very adult in nature and the gore and heavy themes are what you'd expect from a "Walking Dead" branded product.  What I found most interesting was the "illusion of choice" that seemed to be woven throughout the game.  Many people complain that every dialogue option and every choice you make should have an effect on the outcome of the game and many do; however, there are more than several situations in the game where no matter what you do something is going to go down in a certain way - many times in a way that could shock you.  As such, I recommend playing this game by the seat of your pants, don't reload, don't try again.  It's a more rewarding experience in the end since probably that one thing you didn't want to happen is going to happen regardless of what actions you take.  This can be seen as a pro or a con depending on your personality.  I find it a plus, as it allows Telltale's writers to weave a tighter narrative that has a much larger effect on the viewer than if everything turned into sunshine and rainbows for you (which is not going to happen anyway).  Leave it for a second playthrough if you must, but imagine this game as more interacting with a movie that you can steer around as you please to explore the world and interact with the characters in.  SPOILER FOLLOWS - Finally the ending wasn't too fulfilling to me, it almost seems like Telltale was holding back for a future release.  I would have liked to see how your 'parenting' options throughout the episodes effected Clem, and allowed you to see what kind of person she becomes after the credits roll.  Even if her actions post ending were in a montage format that would have been fine, allowing you to see if Clem can survive in this world with the lessons you've taught her. /SPOILERSPros:Great storytelling (narrative, themes, camerawork, "whole-package", etc.)Heavy, adult themes Cons:Minor point-and-click pitfallsEnding didn't "wrap up" to my satisfactionSome characters (while good) felt a little static or seemed to be only "plot-devices"Even though I wasn't too impressed with the ending and the cons *appear* to outlist the pros this game is definitely worth a playthrough.  The story is great and this game is a great entrance for any gamer into interactive storytelling and what poing-and-click adventure games can be. B+

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2013
												If you look from the point of this not being a game and infact being a story then it is beautiful. The way Telltale managed to tell the story while giving you some involvemnet was captivating, true your choices don't really account for much (if someones gonna die, you can't save them) but still with each decision you will make different characters respond to you in different ways.The graphics, while not amazing for a game released in 2012, are beautiful, the comic-booky look works really well with the story feeling of the game. Voice acting is astounding and the music helps to keep the atmosphere. It is a little glitchy/buggy, but hardly enough for you to take notice of given then compelling side of the story telling.The characters are good, each with their own history. You can almost get to know these people, feel emotion with them as if you were actually Lee, it is submersive and it does this aspect well. You start the game in a police car on your way to jail,the car then hits a 'walker' and crashes its way off the road into a small wooded area. You have escaped jail, you are given a second chance at life, well too bad that second chance just happens to fall at the begining of a zombie apoc. You encounter a small child and take her under your wing, protecting her as if she was your own child, trying to always look out for her, do your best for her, ultimately ensuring her safety above your own. Travelling from place to place with the survivors you round up on your journey eventually endind up in the city of Savannah, this is where things got complicated for me, the ending. It is lacking, the last chapter and the things that happen in it just made me scream WTF, the actions of a certain person not justified fully enough to account for the things they are trying to do. It is a poor ending and after being so submerged in the rest of the game this kinda ruined it for me slightly, although I still enjoyed the game and the final, final, final bit was great.Overall it is really a point and click adventure/visual movie with minimal input and not infact a 'game', but it made me feel emotion and it kept me entertained for 16 hours, I'd play through again too, just to make different choices, even though I know they won't affect the overall game.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												First of all, if you think that this game is like your traditional point n click game (like Nancy Drew) then this game is not the game your looking for because Telltale Series game are a bit more than just point n click, You control the actions, relationships and dialogoues of the characters in the story.  The Walking Dead is a Telltale Game Series where your decisions affect the flow of the story and not the actual ending itself. You decide what dialogues you see fit for the situation and the actions you choose affects your relationship towards the other characters.If you want to embody your own personality into the protagonist (Lee Everett) then go for it. You might even know what it feels like to make tough decisions and what it feels to make big sacrifices. This game is not just choosing dialogues but also interacting with the environment. (but not like Nancy Drew)The story is totally very good. It would make you feel like your watching the series itself. The ending is very sad and touching. It can make you shed tears.This game is really worth buying but I recommend that you buy it when it's on sale (preferrably a daily deal) so that you'll be able to buy the DLC and Season 2 for a cheaper price.The 400 Days DLC is not worth its price since it's quite very short for the 5 additional characters but what's good about it is that the actions you chose on Season 1 and 400 days will be carried over to Season 2. That's why it's worth buying Season 1, 400 Days and Season 2 altogether. Overall, it's a great game with a totally touching story. By the way, I'm not a fan of the series but I highly recommend it to everyone.Story: 10/10Gameplay: 8/10Graphics: 10/10Music: 10/10Overall: 9.8/10

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												I'm not a zombie genre fan. I think the whole genre is overdone and exhausted. While The Walking Dead S1 is a story about a zombie apocalypse, it's a damn good one, enough for me to highly appreciate the game. Experience the highs and lows of a group attempting to survive the apocalypse through the eyes of Lee Everett. The player becomes immersed into the story, and becomes emotionally attached to the characters. Interact with the game through quick-time actions, and make game changing decisions. Experience is greatly improved if each chapter (five in total) is played through in 1 sitting, so plan ahead and make sure the game needn't be paused midway. Good luck, and may your brains remain inside your head.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												This game is absolutely amazing. But not by standards of games you are used to. This isn't one of those -Grinding, beat up the enemies repeatedly, level up, or run through enviroment kind of games... this is an emotionally involved decision driven game. There are many options for discussion and relationships with characters. Most everything is a cutscene with a choice in between, and there are small puzzles between discussions and a lot of button mashing. The graphics are also unique and most people would struggle to get used to them this day in age, but I don't. I love this game with all my heart, it's amazingly genuine and full of incredible characters that each vary and all feel realistic and sincere. I for one do not call this game boring for its unique gameplay, or ugly for its unique style. So please, try this game, give it a chance, and be in for the experience of your life. I keep coming back for more time with Lee. My total hours played should just tell ya.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Based on the Kirkman graphic novels rather than the TV show, Telltale's The Walking Dead represents a shift in tone for the company, from comedy adventure game necromancers to gut-punching best-of-a-bad-situation simulators!The focus is on a strong narrative that runs through the season, with hard decisions & character development front and centre. Gameplay mostly consists of mild (often guided) exploration, rudimentary inventory management and in-context quick-time events, which serves its function of moving the story along between locations and disasters.If you are a fan of any facet of The Walking Dead (TV or graphic novel) then this is indispensable.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												The Walking Dead is the prototype game in the industry that shows that storytelling and characterization in video games can easily match those we see in movies or television series. Your choices matter here more than anywhere else and can lead to devastation or salvation when you expect it the least. The well written story and your attachment to the characters - main or supporting - will keep you moving forward and make you question every decision you've made before. It's a game of 'what ifs...'. The story begins right on the first day when the epidemic starts. The main character is Lee Everett, who is on his way to jail in a police patrol vehicle when they hit a zombified humanoid they'll refer to as 'Walkers'. After a bit of wandering in a forest we meet Clementine, the eight year old girl whose nanny has also been turned and her parents are cut off in the faraway Savannah. The two start bonding right after they meet and Lee tries to look after her the best he knows. It's a really an emotionally powerful relationship from the gecko that only gets deeper. The game never tries to be unrealistic about the characters and their motives. Their goal is to survive no matter what, and I mean no matter. Not to find out what has happened or get some kind of cure. No. This makes it so interesting, you aren't Superman nor an action hero with unlimited bullets. The characters are real, everyday people that care about their families and themselves.The game has an episodic character. It has 5 episodes each lasting around 2-3 hours that adds up to a total of 12-14 hours of gameplay. Your choices move the story forward and the game sometimes hits you with an impossible choice that will make you wonder minutes after it. Sometimes it's really hard to make a choice, but sometimes it might not even matter in the end. You just never know when somebody steps in and changes everything. It's a great balance of making up your mind and not knowing what would've happened if. What is spectacular about the game that the other characters have their own stories and plans too, and it might not tally with your's. The rest if the cast isn't there to make your life comfortable. They aren't soulless vessels that obey everything you say. They can act on their own, even if you don't like it and often confront your choices.As a Telltale game it has a comic book character that is unquestionable unique, but hardly state of art. Neither artistically nor technically is a phenomenal game, but it has its own tone. It has other problems too. Frame-rate drops are annoying and camera angle changes can result in a momentary freeze of screen. On the audio front the situation is much better. The music and the voice acting is top notch, that supports the deep and emotional story.Telltale has hit the mark with The Walking Dead: Season 1. It's a spectacular point-and-click game where puzzles are secondary to the story. Yes, there will be times when you have to ask questions like, 'how to make this happen?' or 'how to make that work?', but those are only evanescent. The real question that you'll ask all the time is 'what is the right decision?' But you'll find out that there isn't one. It's a cruel world where everybody tries to survive and some tries to retain their humanity. If you're trying to find a superb interactive story, look no further, because The Walking Dead is a must have experience.Rating: 84/100; Replay Value: 5/5; To Beat: 12-14 hours.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												HOOOOOOO boi. What a game this is. So if you're looking at this review then you're probably wondering, what is The Walking Dead? Well, it's a 5 part episodic game made by TellTale Games based on the comic series "The Walking Dead". That was a mouthful, but yeah basically, this is a game where your choices affect the story. How, you ask? Well, simple enough. I'll explain it to you. Imagine that there are two people and you need to save one, who would you save? Guy A or Guy B? Who you choose will affect certain outcomes in the game but it doesn't change that much here. Stuff like will you save this guy or not? Basically those things. Moving on, it's time to start the review.Story: ( I won't spoil much)You are Lee Everett, a man convicted of killing a man who slept with your wife. You are sentenced to life time to serve in prison, you get in the car with the police officer, everything is all right. However, as the car is moving the police officer hits someone and as a result, the car crashes. You gain consciousness and find an exit out of the wrecked car. You see the police officer dead on the ground, you get his keys and uncuff yourself. He comes back alive, however not the state you'd want him to be. You kill him and go into a house you see after escaping from walkers. You find out that this house belongs to a family of a girl named Clementine. As you investigate through the house, you slip on a pool of blood and a walker attacks you. You have to kill her with the help of Clementine. It works, and she dies. Then you have to decide if you'll go find help in the dark or in the morning. (summary ends here)The story is pretty great, there were a lot of twists I wasn't really expecting on the way. It gets better and better every episode, more so with the final one. I loved Episode 5, it was really great imo. Perfect execution and ending. TellTale nailed it with the story.Characters:I for one would say that the characters in this game are really fleshed out. They feel real and can leave an impact on you. You might be asking yourself, "why would Lee go out on his way to protect Clementine all the time?". Well, that's quite a question but it's easily answered. He takes care of Clem because he wants to be there when her parents aren't, and adding up to that, he always wanted kids of his own. Going back to the characters. There's one character I didn't like much. Particularly Lily. I won't go into detail but, you want to care for her and understand her but then she does something really really bad. I didn't forgive her. Another character that isn't liked much as well is Ben. Why isn't he liked? Well, he gets a lot of people killed and is the cause of a chain of events that happens inbetween 2 episodes. He puts the group in danger because of his clumsiness and cowardness. He's a good guy but he's not really dependable.Sound:The gunfire sounds are pretty good. The sound of hitting stuff is good too. The sounds the walkers make are believable I guess. I don't know much about the music since I didn't really put my attention to it but that ending song is great. The one thing I know that is good is the voice acting. The voice actors really did a fantastic job in voicing their characters. Everyone's voice was pretty good, all scenes were acted really well. Graphics:I love the art style of TellTale so I like the cellshaded graphics that they did for it. Graphics aren't that amazing but they're good to me. They put a lot of work into the art and I can see that well. Overall great graphics.Gameplay:Not that much gameplay since it's an interactive story game but I like the gameplay. It's simple point and click. The shooting parts were fun too. As for the choices, TellTale again did a good job by making me pause for a while and think of what to do before choosing. And that concludes my review of The Walking Dead.Story 10/10Characters: 9/10Sound: 9/10Graphics: 9/10Gameplay: 8.5/10

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												This game is pure interactive story more than anything. There are a few puzzles, some quicktime sequences to keep you on your toes, but more than anything it's a game that sells itself entirely on the strength of its narrative. If that's not what you're looking for, this won't be for you. Character models and animations are a bit dated, lip-syncing is pretty average, nothing about this game on a technical level really stands out. But as an interactive story, I can honestly say I've never felt so invested in a group of fictional characters before. Everyone is flawed but usually sympathetic, and the protagonist and his constant child companion are some of the most likeable characters in games.Even if Lee isn't a generic "everyman", you learn to very quickly identify with him and see things from his perspective, and Clementine is perhaps the only well-done child character in any video game ever. She's realistic, she's cute, she's scared, and she looks up to you. Every action you end up taking will end up going through the filter of "what will Clem think?", and the writing and acting does a wonderful job making you really live with your decisions. Despite the many player choices, this isn't a heavily branching story. The overall plot remains relatively the same regardless of what you do, though the fate of the supporting cast can vary. More than a branching plot, it wants to make it feel like your story, that everything that happens is a result of your choices, and it loves to make you feel guilty, whatever you end up doing. The writing and acting are excellent, and it's an emotionally brutal story in a way so rarely pulled off in games. Even if you don't like this kind of game, even if you don't even like zombies, this is a devastatingly sad tale that really needs to be experienced for yourself, if you can see past the limitations of the game built to tell it.

You may feel cheated. You may feel repulsed. And this game is not for the faint of heart.But if you ever hope to fully understand yourself, and others, you will play this game.Play this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2012
												The Walking Dead Season 1 is an episodic movie series, ONLY it's interactive which means you're both playing a game & watching a movie at the same time.Who Are The Developers:This game is developed by the brilliant minds at Telltale Interactive, who not only create games but they create storybooks inside games.About The Game:The Walking Dead is all about choices, choices that in the end may have dire consiquences & in terms alter the games experience each playthrough and throughout it's multiple episodes.The Review:In Season 1 of The Walking Dead you play as the main protaganist, Lee Everett, who is on his way to prison on day 1 of the Outbreak for commiting a fellony.Right off the bat you're thrust into the story that is both compelling to play through & complete & so  entertaining that awaiting each episode felt like what the Television series feels like while it is on break, it makes you want more & the lust of satisfication can only come from completing it as each new episode gets you even more sucked in.The story is 100% top notch and it not only makes you feel like you have to do everything in your power to protect Lee & Clementine (the secondary protagonist in Season 1 & the main protagonist in Season 2) from harm, this game forces you upon some VERY tough decisions but expects you to make them so quickly at the same time, otherwise death is grasping you and choking the life out of you while it sinks it's teeth in to your soft neck.During the episodes of The Walking Dead, you make choices that affect the entire game each episode & as i said early this creates a domino effect on the next episode that can either be a good thing or a bad thing, so make sure you're 100% about what choices you make.This game creates all types of different emotions, it can create: Suspence Fear Horror Happiness Sadness And on the final episode can even bring your emotions so low it can induce crying in even the toughest people. (Because the final episode is so heartbreaking & you feel as if all the work you've put into the game is being let out during the last few minutes of the episode).The Verdict:This game is an emotinal rollercoaster & a DAMN fine interactive story at that, it is one which if you're a fan of the the TV Series or even the Comic Books you'll be wanting to buy, even if you're not into The Walking Dead and are just looking for a story driven game then this game is for you & i can 100% guarentee that. (I swear on my life!)This game gets a 10 out of 10 from me.Why does it get a 10 out of 10? Because it's so damn good, it has a strong story, each and every character you meet feels like they are a real person & you're in control of each and every friendship or enemy you make in this game, if you make someone a friend then you're going to be treated like a friend and that friend will come through thick or thin to save your♥♥♥♥♥if you're in need of assistance but if you make somebody an enemy then you'll feel the hate from them with every choice you make and that will make the game a lot more difficult, so choose your friends carefully.Not only these few things but each episode brings new dangers to face & more hard decisions to make which all bring you 1 step closer to the absolutely beautiful but terribly depressing finale which will have you almost in tears (if not in tears anyway).Do I Recommend This Game?:Really do i need to say this? YES of course i do with 1 hand on my heart and a straight back i will stand by my purchase with this & NEVER ASK FOR MY MONEY BACK!BRING ON SEASON 2 AND ALL IT'S EPISODES I NEED MORE!Check Out My Review For Season 2:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Paddles01/recommended/261030/

												HOOOOOOO boi. What a game this is. So if you're looking at this review then you're probably wondering, what is The Walking Dead? Well, it's a 5 part episodic game made by TellTale Games based on the comic series "The Walking Dead". That was a mouthful, but yeah basically, this is a game where your choices affect the story. How, you ask? Well, simple enough. I'll explain it to you. Imagine that there are two people and you need to save one, who would you save? Guy A or Guy B? Who you choose will affect certain outcomes in the game but it doesn't change that much here. Stuff like will you save this guy or not? Basically those things. Moving on, it's time to start the review.Story: ( I won't spoil much)You are Lee Everett, a man convicted of killing a man who slept with your wife. You are sentenced to life time to serve in prison, you get in the car with the police officer, everything is all right. However, as the car is moving the police officer hits someone and as a result, the car crashes. You gain consciousness and find an exit out of the wrecked car. You see the police officer dead on the ground, you get his keys and uncuff yourself. He comes back alive, however not the state you'd want him to be. You kill him and go into a house you see after escaping from walkers. You find out that this house belongs to a family of a girl named Clementine. As you investigate through the house, you slip on a pool of blood and a walker attacks you. You have to kill her with the help of Clementine. It works, and she dies. Then you have to decide if you'll go find help in the dark or in the morning. (summary ends here)The story is pretty great, there were a lot of twists I wasn't really expecting on the way. It gets better and better every episode, more so with the final one. I loved Episode 5, it was really great imo. Perfect execution and ending. TellTale nailed it with the story.Characters:I for one would say that the characters in this game are really fleshed out. They feel real and can leave an impact on you. You might be asking yourself, "why would Lee go out on his way to protect Clementine all the time?". Well, that's quite a question but it's easily answered. He takes care of Clem because he wants to be there when her parents aren't, and adding up to that, he always wanted kids of his own. Going back to the characters. There's one character I didn't like much. Particularly Lily. I won't go into detail but, you want to care for her and understand her but then she does something really really bad. I didn't forgive her. Another character that isn't liked much as well is Ben. Why isn't he liked? Well, he gets a lot of people killed and is the cause of a chain of events that happens inbetween 2 episodes. He puts the group in danger because of his clumsiness and cowardness. He's a good guy but he's not really dependable.Sound:The gunfire sounds are pretty good. The sound of hitting stuff is good too. The sounds the walkers make are believable I guess. I don't know much about the music since I didn't really put my attention to it but that ending song is great. The one thing I know that is good is the voice acting. The voice actors really did a fantastic job in voicing their characters. Everyone's voice was pretty good, all scenes were acted really well. Graphics:I love the art style of TellTale so I like the cellshaded graphics that they did for it. Graphics aren't that amazing but they're good to me. They put a lot of work into the art and I can see that well. Overall great graphics.Gameplay:Not that much gameplay since it's an interactive story game but I like the gameplay. It's simple point and click. The shooting parts were fun too. As for the choices, TellTale again did a good job by making me pause for a while and think of what to do before choosing. And that concludes my review of The Walking Dead.Story 10/10Characters: 9/10Sound: 9/10Graphics: 9/10Gameplay: 8.5/10

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Excellent storytelling throughout is where this game is really strong. You do begin to actually care about a lot of the characters which is something most video games are lacking (although admittedly, a lot don't aim for this). This is where the ame truly excels; it will scare you, shock you, make you laugh, probably cry, and in the end you'll just genuinely enjoy it (and after all, isn't that what we all play video games for?).The decisions you make as you go through are also a big selling point. the developers have clearly worked very hard on this aspect, and your decisions will have a very real effect on the game. The decision points are well designed, with almost all of them being difficult choices that really make you think about what you would do in the situation. You also get a breakdown at the end of each episode of how many other players made the same choices as you, which is a nice touch.There is also a very unique graphical style to this game, at first it seems a bit strange, and you could almost accuse the graphics of being "bad", but it gives a feeling to the game like no other, which can only be a good thing.The gameplay is a bit lacklustre, and at times frustrating; you'll probably find yourself thinking you didn't really deserve to die there more than a few times. This gameplay often consists of quicktime events, so it isn't exactly the most revolutionary game in that regard, but they are at least used to relatively good effect though; they seem to be mainly used as a way to keep the player engaged, often occuring when you don't expect it and making you spring into action. This, in part, means that you don't get bored during a long play session, and the episodic nature of the game serves to further break it up; playing through one episode takes a couple of hours, much more and you'd start to get bored.To sum up; this game feels very different to any other I've played. The storytelling is fantastic, the graphics are neither good or bad, but certainly different, and while the gameplay leaves a bit to be desired, it takes a back seat so it really won't bother you. I would recommend this game to anyone 9/10

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Based on the Kirkman graphic novels rather than the TV show, Telltale's The Walking Dead represents a shift in tone for the company, from comedy adventure game necromancers to gut-punching best-of-a-bad-situation simulators!The focus is on a strong narrative that runs through the season, with hard decisions & character development front and centre. Gameplay mostly consists of mild (often guided) exploration, rudimentary inventory management and in-context quick-time events, which serves its function of moving the story along between locations and disasters.If you are a fan of any facet of The Walking Dead (TV or graphic novel) then this is indispensable.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Hats off to the best story game ever!TL;DR version available below.The Walking Dead is an episodic interactive drama graphic adventure video game developed and published by Telltale Games. Based on Robert Kirkman's The Walking Dead comic book series, the first season consists of five episodes and having some extra episodes only available with the 400 Days DLC. There's later The Walking Dead Season 2 aswell, so buy that aswell if you're planning to buy this one.The game takes place in the same fictional world as the comic, with events occurring shortly after the onset of the zombie apocalypse in Georgia. However, most of the characters are original to the game, which centers on university professor and convicted murderer Lee Everett, who helps to rescue and subsequently care for a young girl named Clementine. Telltale did an awesome job creating such a brilliant game. They've maintained the level of story and gameplay so that you won't notice any flaws. Unlike many graphic adventure games, The Walking Dead does not emphasize puzzle solving, but instead focuses on story and character development. The story is affected by both the dialogue choices of the player and their actions during quick time events (QTE). If you aren't good with QTE games, it'll take you quite a time to do finish any objective then.There's everything in this game, which goes from good scene to disturbing one, tense one, or the heart breaking. It's one a hell enjoying story I've ever played. I wouldn't mind buying another series by Telltale because I love how they made this, those graphical works, environment, and stuff, all are best.Rating: 9.9/10TL;DR If you want to enjoy an awesome story line and wanted to get emotional in real life, you should try this out.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												The Walking Dead is an interesting visual novel/point and click type of game. When I first went into it I thought it was about  talking to my group and trying to change their fates through our interactions. I was horribly disappointing to realize no matter what you do or what you say, the outcome is always the same. There is a huge amount of "illusion of choice" There is one point in the game where you have to choose between saving this guy or saving this girl. When you save one, the other dies and the story goes in a different direction and encourages replaying the game! Right? Wrong. Not twenty minutes later, the person you save dies anyways. In the end no matter your choice, both end up dead. There was no choice! This pattern continued through the whole game, I'd be promoted with a choice and the inevitable would eventually happen. I finished the game with a bad taste in my mouth. That is until I saw a discussion online about Kenny, one of the characters. The thread started off with someone saying how awesome Kenny was.He always had your back, was friendly, sacrificed himself, he was cool. I agreed. However most people in the thread said he was a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥! I was completely in disagreement! They were even listing quotes he NEVER said in the game! That was when it hit me. The events of the game are unchangeable but the characters and the way they interact with you is completely different for each player depending on your choices. Kenny was a nice guy in my game but a jerk in many other people's games. It made discussion about the game a ton of fun since everyone's experience with each character was completely different. Some characters tell some players things other players will never hear them say.Sure the events were out of your control but that kind of game would be a little high budget for Telltale, so I think what they pulled off was pretty well done all things considered. My advice is do NOT go into the game with the thought that you can change the outcome of certain character's gruesome fates, but you can change their personalities, and compare the differences and similarities between your characters and your friend's characters' personalities. Your "best bro" in your game could be your friend's biggest rival or worst enemy!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2013
												Telltale's The Walking Dead is based on the canon of the hit TV Show and graphic novel series.  It is a point-and-click adventure game with quicktime elements - and it's a very good one.  The narrative, storytelling, and characterization is top notch and if one can refer to a story as "heavy" this game is more like having a pickup truck sitting on your chest.  It's a prime example of interactive storytelling and is an excellent model of how you can use the gaming medium to convey a story to an audience - even the camera angles it utilizes were wonderful, from staring at your reflection in a puddle as you beat someone's brain in to adding tension by having a skewed angle while you climb a ladder.  The game did have some pitfalls that comes with the point-and-click genre that it didn't avoicd unfortunately - repeatedly viewing things instead of acting on them/with them, repeating dialogue options accidentally without the ability to skip them, a few character and graphics glitches (I vividly remember speaking to an invisible Vernon and Kat cradling an invisible Duck in her arms) but besides a 4th wall breaking comic intervention these small negatives don't detract too much from the story as a whole.  The plot is very adult in nature and the gore and heavy themes are what you'd expect from a "Walking Dead" branded product.  What I found most interesting was the "illusion of choice" that seemed to be woven throughout the game.  Many people complain that every dialogue option and every choice you make should have an effect on the outcome of the game and many do; however, there are more than several situations in the game where no matter what you do something is going to go down in a certain way - many times in a way that could shock you.  As such, I recommend playing this game by the seat of your pants, don't reload, don't try again.  It's a more rewarding experience in the end since probably that one thing you didn't want to happen is going to happen regardless of what actions you take.  This can be seen as a pro or a con depending on your personality.  I find it a plus, as it allows Telltale's writers to weave a tighter narrative that has a much larger effect on the viewer than if everything turned into sunshine and rainbows for you (which is not going to happen anyway).  Leave it for a second playthrough if you must, but imagine this game as more interacting with a movie that you can steer around as you please to explore the world and interact with the characters in.  SPOILER FOLLOWS - Finally the ending wasn't too fulfilling to me, it almost seems like Telltale was holding back for a future release.  I would have liked to see how your 'parenting' options throughout the episodes effected Clem, and allowed you to see what kind of person she becomes after the credits roll.  Even if her actions post ending were in a montage format that would have been fine, allowing you to see if Clem can survive in this world with the lessons you've taught her. /SPOILERSPros:Great storytelling (narrative, themes, camerawork, "whole-package", etc.)Heavy, adult themes Cons:Minor point-and-click pitfallsEnding didn't "wrap up" to my satisfactionSome characters (while good) felt a little static or seemed to be only "plot-devices"Even though I wasn't too impressed with the ending and the cons *appear* to outlist the pros this game is definitely worth a playthrough.  The story is great and this game is a great entrance for any gamer into interactive storytelling and what poing-and-click adventure games can be. B+

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												As a standalone game, The Walking Dead is excellent. I specifically say standalone, as there is a sequel, and it's very obvious from the ending of the first one that there was more story left to tell. Unfortunately, the sequel shames the greatness of the first game. So, if you're able to enjoy the game on its own merits, despite the emptiness from the story not being continued after the final episode, I would definitely recommend it.The Walking Dead is in many ways a story first, then a game. The main interactivty comes in with adjusting the way the story goes to your liking. The player character, Lee, can be as compassionate, morally grey, or obnoxious as you like, despite the presence of his moral compass so to speak, the young girl Clementine, whose parents have been lost to the zombie apocalypse. Granted, Lee will still show he cares a great deal for Clementine even if you make him a complete jerk, but you can still play him in a way that'd make it seem like poor Clementine would be better off without him. If you try to play the compassionate route, all the moral dilemmas that the zombie apocalypse throws at you may make you realise that doing the right thing isn't always so clear!It should be made clear, this is a story that revolves around the characters, as does the interactivty. Do not expect major branching, or even really much branching at all, in the plot. But do expect some variety in how long certain characters stick around and how they act towards Lee depending on what you have him say and do. Chances are, you're going to come out of this game wondering just how confident you are in your own morals.The biggest flaw of the game as it stands on its own is by far the lack of bug removal. You probably won't run into anything major playing through it once, but if you replay it, which isn't exactly an odd choice when I've played through it about 8 times and still haven't seen everything, you become more likely to have your save messed up, or the cursor refusing to go all the way to the right of the screen, and so on. On a technical level it's appalling how little Telltale cared.If you can get past the fact it doesn't really feel like a complete story due to the lack of a good second season, the fact your choices only affect characters to a degree, and the horde of bugs, this is a good game. Hell, before the second season really went to crap during its final two episodes, I barely had a bad thing to say about this game, the main gripe really is that its sequel is so bad. If you want an extremely immersive, gripping, emotional interactive story, this may be a good place to look!

content:
Posted: January 19, 2013
												Telltale's The Walking Dead is based on the canon of the hit TV Show and graphic novel series.  It is a point-and-click adventure game with quicktime elements - and it's a very good one.  The narrative, storytelling, and characterization is top notch and if one can refer to a story as "heavy" this game is more like having a pickup truck sitting on your chest.  It's a prime example of interactive storytelling and is an excellent model of how you can use the gaming medium to convey a story to an audience - even the camera angles it utilizes were wonderful, from staring at your reflection in a puddle as you beat someone's brain in to adding tension by having a skewed angle while you climb a ladder.  The game did have some pitfalls that comes with the point-and-click genre that it didn't avoicd unfortunately - repeatedly viewing things instead of acting on them/with them, repeating dialogue options accidentally without the ability to skip them, a few character and graphics glitches (I vividly remember speaking to an invisible Vernon and Kat cradling an invisible Duck in her arms) but besides a 4th wall breaking comic intervention these small negatives don't detract too much from the story as a whole.  The plot is very adult in nature and the gore and heavy themes are what you'd expect from a "Walking Dead" branded product.  What I found most interesting was the "illusion of choice" that seemed to be woven throughout the game.  Many people complain that every dialogue option and every choice you make should have an effect on the outcome of the game and many do; however, there are more than several situations in the game where no matter what you do something is going to go down in a certain way - many times in a way that could shock you.  As such, I recommend playing this game by the seat of your pants, don't reload, don't try again.  It's a more rewarding experience in the end since probably that one thing you didn't want to happen is going to happen regardless of what actions you take.  This can be seen as a pro or a con depending on your personality.  I find it a plus, as it allows Telltale's writers to weave a tighter narrative that has a much larger effect on the viewer than if everything turned into sunshine and rainbows for you (which is not going to happen anyway).  Leave it for a second playthrough if you must, but imagine this game as more interacting with a movie that you can steer around as you please to explore the world and interact with the characters in.  SPOILER FOLLOWS - Finally the ending wasn't too fulfilling to me, it almost seems like Telltale was holding back for a future release.  I would have liked to see how your 'parenting' options throughout the episodes effected Clem, and allowed you to see what kind of person she becomes after the credits roll.  Even if her actions post ending were in a montage format that would have been fine, allowing you to see if Clem can survive in this world with the lessons you've taught her. /SPOILERSPros:Great storytelling (narrative, themes, camerawork, "whole-package", etc.)Heavy, adult themes Cons:Minor point-and-click pitfallsEnding didn't "wrap up" to my satisfactionSome characters (while good) felt a little static or seemed to be only "plot-devices"Even though I wasn't too impressed with the ending and the cons *appear* to outlist the pros this game is definitely worth a playthrough.  The story is great and this game is a great entrance for any gamer into interactive storytelling and what poing-and-click adventure games can be. B+

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												“So, you think you’re strong, right?You think you can last longer, take more pressure. You know what’s best for yourself as well as for the people around you. Right?Right. Let’s put you to the test.”That’s what The Walking Dead is essentially about. What we’re looking at is… †checks her game record† …a 14-hour game-movie-story. For most people this will be an exceptionally intense experience. This is far less about standard gaming than it is about storytelling, & the story being told will put you through a handful. That’s what it means to do. As the story unfolds you’re confronted with many decisions, most of which are neither easy to make nor to be taken lightly. Nearly all of them you have to make under genuine pressure. The game doesn’t judge; this is up to yourself. It, however, observes carefully. Even though not all of your decisions seem to have a massive & immediate influence on what happens next, everything you do is noted.The Walking Dead as a story has quite a radical way of handling its protagonists. Something similar you might get to see in a horror movie… The game doesn’t make much of an effort to wait for you to catch up. The pressure is on everyone; on the people inside the story as well as on you, the outsider playing the game. It’s a good thing that there are several chapters/episodes, & finishing one of them does not, immediately push you into the next. So you get breathers. Time to think, time to look back, even a chance to actually go back in time & do things differently if you so decide. It’s still furiously intense, fiercely confrontational. If you make your way through this & it makes you feel like you just got pushed through a mixer, don’t worry; everything’s purrfectly fine. So you think you’re strong. Right? You think you’re a toughie, a hero, a leader. Right? Then go ahead, try this. You'll have to prove it to this story.-†kali

content:
Posted: November 4, 2013
												The Walking Dead is not another zombie game, it's a game that happened to have zombie apocalypse in it but main focus is on characters. Game explores interactions in a closed group of people and you often are forced to make hard decisions whenever you like it or not. What i noticed early on that not every stranger you meet in game is honest or open with you. Often you'll be faced with situations that requires somekind of trust and you just cannot trust someone for whatever reason. Everything you do or say has consequences in one way or another and sooner or later you'll have to face them. At the end of every chapter you get little chart showing your choices and what other players picked. Main protagonist is Lee. A black guy who has a secret which he (you) can reveal to the rest of group or not. Lee early on in the game finds a little girl Clementine. After Lee finds Clem he promises her to find her parents and they travel together from then on. Even though Lee isn't Clementine's dad he sure does care about her like it's his own daughter, giving her symphaty and tips when she need it. The game is worth to play just to see how those two interact. Also note that Clementine isn't boring nor annoying for a child character. Possibly best portrayed child character ever in video games. Overall I'd give this game 10/10 even though this doesn't feel like a "real" game but I have to question what is a game? This is exemplar of "chose your own adventure" book. Story has great pacing, nice soundtrack and tension where it's needed. It is unbelievable how good this game story is so I highly recommend to play it for everyone even those who don't play many games.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Lots of nice situations, often times without the option you would want.. but what do you expect - and it all goes down alright for the sake of story.The game is quite good, quite lengthy and the final chapter quite impressed me. I enjoyed it as a whole and I recall a lot of it despite playing the 5 seasons over approximately 18 months.There are some great characters and some great situations. The game holds your hand a lot, but it's mainly a story-telling experience anyway - the only issue I had with the gameplay was the lengthy *actions* that can trigger if I clicked something twice, which you might do if you think that your character (Lee) might have the same insight you have (not often the case). Nonetheless, the game is fun and I recommend you play it, though probably picked up on a good sale tbh.My biggest peeve was that a good number of episodes were driven by character interactions between your group, but the game never presented me with the option I wanted (namely who I should be accusing). I found it weird as much of the game was about managing relationships AND ACCUSATIONS, but the time that I most wanted to accuse somebody of the poison that saw massive change (and the loss of the single group member that I wanted to keep), there was no option to remove the single most destructive group member (my opinion for a while before that happened, and ultimately proven by the end of the game to be your *worst* team member).I hope Telltale Games grow a pair and tell their funding groups that they want to make a more ambitious game. From what I've heard, they may already have done so.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2013
												As a fan of the first season of the show, I really wanted this game to work. It was recommended to me as a great story driven game with deep charcters. And it is exactly that, but more!Not really enjoying this genre - I was beyond pleasantly suprised with the game! It made me reconsider my thoughts on the genre as a whole.The word as we all know it has ended. Zombie craziness has ensued. You are Lee, you are riding in the back of a police car when the game begins. You'll find a small child and become responsible for her and here is where the similarities between your playthrough and mine will end!Your game will be shaped by the choices you make, or don't make, the things you say, or don't say and the people you save, or don't...The game has an understandably small cast, because, you know, the world has ended.The charcters you encounter are well written and believable. Resulting in sometimes agonising choices that need to be made. I found myself really caring about the charcters and wanting to do what's best for them all. This is a credit to the game designers who have done an outstanding job with designing them .As Lee you will have limited time to read through the choices and shape the game you want to play. This game will demand a reply if only to find out what would have happened if you'd said something different at that critical moment!Decisions I made in the first episode are coming back to haunt me even now, in the middle of episode 4!Although there are no real brain crushing puzzels to be found, there are a few basic ones to be solved and that's fine.The puzzles never get too trying or boring and are broken up very nicely by bludgeoning, slashing, stabbing and a general variety of very satisfying zombie killsA great introduction to the genre and a great game in general too!

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												I never was very fond of zombies. I only watched the first and half of the second season of The Walking Dead TV-show and each other (post-)apocalyptic scenario (as War against Machines, Nuclear Holocaust, Alien Invasion or global Eco-Disaster) I prefer over a zombie apocalypse - both in real life and in video games. But if you are interested in a strong narrative and a video game triggering emotions like a great movie would do, then there is no way around Telltale's The Walking Dead. The gameplay is minimalistic. You click on already highlighted objects/persons to push the story forward but not to solve any puzzles or riddles or fill your inventory as you may expect from an adventure game. Even "Heavy Rain" was more of a game than The Walking Dead is, but this is interactive storytelling at its best.The great voice-acting makes all the characters you meet reasonable and authentic. Actually Melissa Hutchison (who speaks Clementine) won the “Best Performance by a Female" at the 2013 Spike Video Games Awards.Oh well, talking about Clementine. Usually children in video games are just plain annoying or they are drawn in an unlikely precocious way acting like adults with their bodyscale set to 0.6. Not so here. I can't imagine the cold-hearted kitty-slaying villain you have to be to not care about Clementine and do whatever it takes to guide her safely through this horror. It broke my heart when we had to part.So eventually you will figure that all your gameplay- and dialogue choices won't even change the outcome of the story but just how your fellow companions stand towards you and whether if they like you or not. And maybe that is the most important lesson we can distill off The Walking Dead for the upcoming apocalypse – both in real life and in video games.First playthrough: ~15 hrs.Here is a three episode mini-series from Extra Credits about various topics relating to Telltale's The Walking Dead. (minor Spoilers)


YouTube™ Video: Raising the Dead - How Walking Dead Revived Adventure Games - Extra Credits 

			Views: 240,736		

			This week, we begin a three week series on various topics relating to Telltalle's The Walking Dead. Come discuss this topic in the forums!

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Never thought I'd see anything top the experience of Mass Effect so soon. I have only played through this game once, but you could feel how the game not only set you in front of a choice but also expected you to deal with it. No good, no bad, just "hope you can live with the consequences", all with a story that you can't help but get emotionally invested in (keep tissues nearby). The game reflects on and compares your decisions throughout the game with gathered data from Telltale at the end of every episode if you have an internet connection.The game focuses on story, in the purest way I've ever seen a game execute it. It still clings a little too much to the pace-killing puzzles of the Monkey Island era, but the puzzle areas are generally very small (the probably largest area in the game is a hallway, two rooms and a backyard) and the usual "use every item on every item on the screen until something happens" procedure is simplified by the compact and confined GUI.Other than that, you spend most of your time talking to people and watching cutscenes. Many cutscenes involve quicktime events to reenforce that you have to take account of your actions and promises. Have you promised to shoot someone? The game puts you back in control and expects you to pull the trigger with a mouse click.♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥a guy in your party? You better defend yourself by smashing Q when he jumps on your throat.Dialogs are often timed too to add to the tension, and give you the option to willingly stay silent when they are. In my opinion, the silent option adds very well to the immersion in a couple of conversations where none of the other options could accurately express what I/my character was thinking. The writing of the dialogs and the voice acting are excellent and create believable characters.The game is very consistent and not only respects your choices, but also has some of the characters remember very well what you do. For example, you can be caught if you lie and contradict yourself in a later conversation. I've found no immersion or cohesion breaking bugs (Concelor Anderson anyone?), the game generally does a very good job at keeping the Fourth Wall intact once you've become used to the quicktime events.I think games are still figuring out how to perform incredible storytelling and The Walking Dead delivers an experience that I'm looking forward to see serving as an inspiration for a new generation of adventure games. I recommend this game wholeheartedly to everyone who is not ashamed of crying in front of a computer screen.P.S. I also highly recommend watching the Extra Credits Mini-Series on this game, starting with this one:

												Absolutely amazing interactive movie that runs around 10 hours.  Real time decision making that has dire consequences.  It takes place in the world of The Walking Dead, but doesn't really touch the TV show story or have any relation aside from seeing one of the characters from it very briefy in the start of the game.   The game gives you the same feeling of wanting to know what the next chapter will bring as any other amazing series.The visuals are great, and the story will take you on an emotional rollercoaster. Highly recommended to everyone, even those who are not familiar with the source material.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2013
												As a fan of the first season of the show, I really wanted this game to work. It was recommended to me as a great story driven game with deep charcters. And it is exactly that, but more!Not really enjoying this genre - I was beyond pleasantly suprised with the game! It made me reconsider my thoughts on the genre as a whole.The word as we all know it has ended. Zombie craziness has ensued. You are Lee, you are riding in the back of a police car when the game begins. You'll find a small child and become responsible for her and here is where the similarities between your playthrough and mine will end!Your game will be shaped by the choices you make, or don't make, the things you say, or don't say and the people you save, or don't...The game has an understandably small cast, because, you know, the world has ended.The charcters you encounter are well written and believable. Resulting in sometimes agonising choices that need to be made. I found myself really caring about the charcters and wanting to do what's best for them all. This is a credit to the game designers who have done an outstanding job with designing them .As Lee you will have limited time to read through the choices and shape the game you want to play. This game will demand a reply if only to find out what would have happened if you'd said something different at that critical moment!Decisions I made in the first episode are coming back to haunt me even now, in the middle of episode 4!Although there are no real brain crushing puzzels to be found, there are a few basic ones to be solved and that's fine.The puzzles never get too trying or boring and are broken up very nicely by bludgeoning, slashing, stabbing and a general variety of very satisfying zombie killsA great introduction to the genre and a great game in general too!

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												I never was very fond of zombies. I only watched the first and half of the second season of The Walking Dead TV-show and each other (post-)apocalyptic scenario (as War against Machines, Nuclear Holocaust, Alien Invasion or global Eco-Disaster) I prefer over a zombie apocalypse - both in real life and in video games. But if you are interested in a strong narrative and a video game triggering emotions like a great movie would do, then there is no way around Telltale's The Walking Dead. The gameplay is minimalistic. You click on already highlighted objects/persons to push the story forward but not to solve any puzzles or riddles or fill your inventory as you may expect from an adventure game. Even "Heavy Rain" was more of a game than The Walking Dead is, but this is interactive storytelling at its best.The great voice-acting makes all the characters you meet reasonable and authentic. Actually Melissa Hutchison (who speaks Clementine) won the “Best Performance by a Female" at the 2013 Spike Video Games Awards.Oh well, talking about Clementine. Usually children in video games are just plain annoying or they are drawn in an unlikely precocious way acting like adults with their bodyscale set to 0.6. Not so here. I can't imagine the cold-hearted kitty-slaying villain you have to be to not care about Clementine and do whatever it takes to guide her safely through this horror. It broke my heart when we had to part.So eventually you will figure that all your gameplay- and dialogue choices won't even change the outcome of the story but just how your fellow companions stand towards you and whether if they like you or not. And maybe that is the most important lesson we can distill off The Walking Dead for the upcoming apocalypse – both in real life and in video games.First playthrough: ~15 hrs.Here is a three episode mini-series from Extra Credits about various topics relating to Telltale's The Walking Dead. (minor Spoilers)
