content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
Fantastic story, but lacks gameplay.The Walking Dead tells the story of a Lee Everett, and a small child named Clementine who Lee looks after. It takes place during a zombie appocalypse, and has a very dark setting. While the Walking Dead offers very little gameplay (Mostly Quick-Time Events), it has a very touching story. The game makes you feel like you're talking to real people. It gives you options of what you want to say, and the other characters dialog changes based on your's. The game also offers you other choices differing from conversation. These include who you will give food to, and which people you will save. The game feels incredibly immersive and has a deep story. If you're looking for a plot-based game, pick this game up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												When you first play the game, the one thing that hits you is the art style; Designed around the illustrations of The Walking Dead comics with a completely new cast of characters. The game is solely based on the decisions of the player, from things to say; to pivotal plot points, the game gives you a variety of options to choose from and a limited time to do so. Throughout the game you can get very attached to the characters, one minute everything's fine, the next you're sent into shock as something may have gone horribly wrong. This is what the game does well and builds its story around this alongside the problems and drama you will face. This interesting point and click adventure asks the player to scavenge and be creative with how they handle situations;  using a pillow to silence a gun or even distracting zombies with TVs on display in a store. Also the game has a system where each character will remember your actions and recall them later on in the story; this can be when you don't take sides with someone or when you don't agree with their ideas. This can lead to characters holding grudges or characters willing to back you up.It's episodic format what originally helped the pacing of the game; each ending on a different note that will cause you to buy the next episode to continue those compelling moments of the story much like when you read the hardback comics. Although since all the episodes are out, you can buy all of them together and play through the them all. Honestly the story is what I like about the game the most; this is because at the end you make a choice that will cause you sadness either way; even when Lee is bitten there is no escape from his fate. Even after you've finished playing you will remember the game for it's strong characters, some have which may have died and some may have survived.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2013
												Don't be fooled by the art (which I think is superb btw). This game has a very dark and engaging story filled with profanity and incredibly shocking graphical moments.It sets a new standard in Point-and-Click adventures. I've never played a game that heavily customises the way you perceive the main story based on the choices you've made.There are no wrong choices. Select truthfully and the game will reward you with an outcome that you deserve and will understand. Even if you think it's a bad choice. You'll appreciate the story much more and thank me at the very end.There's probably enough alterations in this game to warrant 2 more play throughs. There's no multiple alternate endings like some games do. All the changes happen as the story is being told. What you do in episode 2 might change something in episode 4. Lee Everett ... lol, what a name XDThe game is about 14 hours in length for first play through. I bought it for $12.50 and no regrets if it goes cheaper the next day.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												When I began "The Walking Dead", I honestly did not know what to expect. The only thing I knew about it before-hand was that it has gotten worldwide critical acclaim and that it was sort of like a point-and-click kind of game, which I'm not too big of a fan of. When I started playing it, however, my thoughts started to change. By the time I had completed episode 1, I was eager to beat the game just to find out what happens. Surprisingly, the game isn't too heavy on gameplay. Instead, the story is what drives the game forward. I was always excited to play the game so I could find out what would happen to the characters. The game has a ton of drama and suspence to spice up the plot, which is needed since the plot is what the game relies on. The fact that the game changes depending on the choices you make is (to me) one of the biggest and greatest features of the game, and it adds a lot of replay value.By the end of the story (which isn't terribly long, maybe 12 hours or so), I had gotten so emotionally attatched to the characters, which made the ending one of the saddest endings I have ever witnessed in a game. It seriously made me teary-eyed. So, in conclusion, "The Walking Dead" isn't heavy on gameplay, but that's not really what the game's supposed to be about, and you just have to adapt to it. It's the story that makes it incredible, especially the fact that it changes depending on the choices you make.9/10, would recommend to anybody who would like a good story or fans of the TV show/comic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												I went into The Walking Dead with few expectations. I was only vaguely familiar with the comic's existence. I believe the show had at least started, but what little I'd seen of it bored me. I wasn't even particularly familiar with Telltale Games at the time, outside of knowing they handled newer takes on the Monkey Island and Sam & Max properties. That was it. And now, I can easily say The Walking Dead remains one of, if not, their best adventure game, even with more of the same world and visits to other worlds adopting the choices-with-consequence model The Walking Dead established.Right off the bat, The Walking Dead manages to establish its setting at a breakneck pace without being confusing or unclear. You're in Georgia. You're in trouble. Then suddenly, you -and- Georgia, and the whole world for that matter, are in a whole lot more trouble than anyone bargained for. The core cast gets established fairly quickly, then the pace begins to ease up a bit to give you time to get comfortable with your new avatar and his associates. Lee, the one left to rot. Clementine, the one left behind. Kenny, the one left to act. And there are plenty of supporting characters, all distinct, many memorable, helping hold up these eventual pillars of the story as well.One point of contrast between how conversations and action sequences is handled in The Walking Dead really struck me: it's the little things, like what you choose to say or whom you choose to say it to, that have the longest-running impact and the greatest effect on your overal experience of the game, and in most cases, there's no undo. Meanwhile, coming back from failure during a quick-time-event, which typically ends in fatality, is almost instant, and is the closest thing to "fixing" any of your actions you get a chance to do. This really helps emphasize the importance of the characters and their interaction over any sort of outside actors or circumstances that is the core of the game on the whole.If you decide to play through The Walking Dead, you're going to cry. You're going to yell, too, and smile. You'll love some characters, you'll hate others. And the best thing is? It's unlikely the moments and people that fit those lists for you will match up exactly with anyone else. Even if you're not a fan of the other Walking Dead media properties, you owe it to yourself to play this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												Telltale's spin on The Walking Dead is in many ways a success. The graphics on the game are pretty good. The story line, though extremely linear, is one that you can definitely enjoy in a single playthrough. The characters are, for the most part, well thought out, and engaging. Lee and Clem are both easy characters to love, along with their entertwining story. **Spoiler Alert** From this point on there will be portions of the game that will give away some of the storyline.  I almost freaked out when they had me dream that she became a walker. O.o  Some of the things that I think would have really pushed this game over the top if they had been better are as follows. The ability to TRULY choose my own story, I've played through many of the episodes 2-3 times trying to gain different outcomes, but it always ends up the same. Even when you choose between saving different people Telltale takes the choice away from you later on so that you have to follow the story line they've laid out.  Take for instance saving Carly or Doug. It doesnt matter because they both die later due to Lilly going insane, and there's NO WAY to stop it from happening. I replayed the episode 3 times before finally googling it to see if there was any way to stop Lilly and found that there wasn't. This to me is the major flaw to this, and all of the other Telltale games. They're not truly unique stories, and you can't truly change the way things happen in the end no matter what you choose. My biggest gripe with this series, as well as the other games I've played of theirs is that I can't really change the story, just a few minor plot points. If you're going to sell a game as a "Choose your own Adventure" type game, then please make it actually be able to be played through multiple times with different outcomes each time based on choices of the player. In closing, I absolutely love the idea behind TWD, and the GoT series by Telltale, however they've sold us majorly short in my opinion on the whole "Choose" part of the adventure, it is nothing more than smoke and mirrors while they push the linear game that they wrote on you as a player. The games at face value are fun to play through once for sure, maybe even twice if you want to change the persona your character has, but not much more than that as the story never really changes.  Would I recommend this game? Yes when it's on sale. Just don't expect as much as I did when buying it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Overall pretty good. The game has a few down points but all in all I would give it 70/100 (50 is average). The game basically follows a group of people surviving the Zpocolypse like the show. It plays as an interactive story and the player makes choices for the main character. There isn't any gameplay really it is just point and click for I would say 75% of the game. The rest are small real time button mashes that you have to do, which are really kinda pointless in my opinion. The good thing about the game is that zombies are actually a pretty big part of the game unlike many "zombie" genre media that turns into nothing but soap operahs with a few zombies in the background as plot motivators. A qucik look around the internet and you will find that people get pretty emotionally invovled in this game, so thats always a good sign. For me, it wasn't as engaging but still well worth the time to go through it. Hard to say much else without spoiling the game for those who haven't played it.For the not-so-good. I think the most fusterating part of the game is the controls. They are very loose and don't always work. The control scheme can be annoyingly difficult to manipulate at times. The other major issue was as with almost all choice based games there are often times when my personal choice just wasn't an option. You get 2 or maybe 3 choices and none of them are what I considered good so your left with just picking the least bad. That kinda kicks you out of the emersion a bit. Lastly, story wise and this is a little bit of a spoiler I guess, but eventually you realize that none of the choices "really" matter in the game. It plays out pretty much exactly as it always will and ends up the same, just the dialogue is a bit different along the way. That is a dissapointment, but understandable considering the game would be huge otherwise and would be pretty hard to navigate the players through a understandable story.Some other critique I have is mostly in the way of graphics. Overall it is a good style and the game looks good, but there are gliches here and there and the animations are sometimes wonky. Nothing game breaking or really bad but a lack of polish nontheless. So overall worth it. If you like this sort of game it is definitely worth picking up. If on the fence, it is worth picking up on a steam sale. I played it straight through and the play time is accurate so probably 12-16 hours for most people.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												Rarely have I seen a story so well developped, characters so lifelike, group dynamics so accurately rendered, a general ambiance so gripping in a videogame. The gameplay itself may be fairly basic, the graphics aren't bad or even bland but they aren't eye candy at all. Yet it hardly matters as this game's forte lies entirely elsewhere. The consequences of your every actions on the story line keep  you constantly wondering, involved and waiting in quiet, tense expectation for whatever will come next. The Walking Dead does not really deliver the horror or adrenaline that the title or scenario suggests, it does not compete with tenors of the survival genre, but it does deliver a deep and long lasting experience and is without a single doubt a masterpiece.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												Quite possibly the best experience I've ever had with a computer (even better than pron).There just aren't word to describe this game (or rather, an interactive movie). The storyline throws though decisions at you at every corner and makes you feel various emotions, especially at the end. Looking back at my play time, it had 21 hours with not much replay value, but feels like so much more and the story is unforgetable. It costs $25, but the experience with making your own choices is priceless. Just buy it100/10 which reduces to a 10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Honestly, I didn't plan on getting this game initially, I had watched a few people play it before, and it felt like it was just another game. But thats when you're a spectator, picking up the game yourself, you have to deal with a whole new reality. This isn't an instance where you can backseat game or pause the video for an answer. You have to act in the there and now, making split second decisions and reactions that otherwise could have dire consequences in how events play out in the story. Granted, the story is a heart jerker, there's no denying that, but if you enjoy a story for a content, the rich life of the seams that exist between the beginning and end of the fabric as it were, then you will play this game. There are many different paths that this game follows, and it is impossible to say which one you will go down. Whether it be on purpose, or you hit a key on accident, you cannot undo what you have done. This game focuses on the reality of living in a world of the dead. While it does follow a set story to an extent, the bonds you build with most of the characters feels real and sincere, the same goes with the friends you don't make. Enemies in small groups you're forced with can often lead to butting heads and arguements even if they only slightly disagree. Weigh your options carefully, and tread softly, in the land of Telltales "The Walking Dead".

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2012
												A very story driven narrative which is well put together. The voice acting and dialogue is good and I found myself invested in the characters. The visual design is very stylised and as a result manages to remain looking great (and will not date) despite not requiring or using current graphical power and techniques.The gameplay is light, being primarily point and click with the occasional QTE or gallery shooting section. Normally this would switch me off but the important thing here is the narrative and this more than makes up for the lack of gameplay elements.People have complained that your decisions do not change the outcomes enough on multiple playthroughs, this is partly true, there are events in the game that are out of your control. I have found that this in some respects is nessesary to keep the narritive tight and can help build a sense of hopelessness as well. More often than not, even if your actions do not change a physical outcome, they do change characters views of you and that can come back to bite you later.All in all I recommend this if you have wanted a story focused zombie apocalypse game and were disapointed with things like the disparity between the dead island trailer and what the game wound up being. It isn't a perfect game (lack of gameplay elements) but it is worth playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
												TLDR - Virtual comic book with QTE.My Rating - 7.5/10Plot:-The game takes place in the same fictional world as the comic, with events occurring shortly after the onset of the zombie apocalypse in Georgia. However, most of the characters are original to the game, which centers on university professor and convicted murderer Lee Everett, who helps to rescue and subsequently care for a young girl named Clementine. Kirkman provided oversight for the game's story to ensure it corresponded to the tone of the comic, but allowed Telltale to handle the bulk of the developmental work and story specifics. Some characters from the original comic book series also make in-game appearances.Although replay value is a little low despite the fact of it being a game that lets you control the outcome of an ending, it is still indeed a thrilling, suspensful and stressful game all at the same time.DLC content (400 Days) was a little disappointing to be honest. Didn't have much back story on it and it was left with a huge cliff hanger. Unlike the original story line, which we all know that it continues off with season 2. But for $3, I guess it wasn't that bad after all.Not the best Telltale series game yet but it still is worth the money if you're a big Walking Dead fan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												OK this game has 20000 reviews so I'll be short. As an adventure game amateur I was really blown away by the great atmosphere, the expressive characters , and the difficult choices this game give you, as well as the alternative endings. The story is really intense, even at times unrealisticly so, but mostly it's well orchestrated, there is a great story in this game.The story and genereal atmosphere and graphic is so great in fact that it might blind you to the flaws of the game. The gameplay in itself is really minimalistic, it's there but compared to the storytelling part of the game, it kind of feels anemic. The puzzles are very simple and\or obvious , and it feels like the designers didn't want anything to go in the way of the story. The quick time events with the weird q button are more annoying than scary, I have gone through the game but I still haven't figured out how it works. I kind of liked the action sequences involving fighting and guns but this was rather primitive as well.  Still it's obvious for me that a "the walking dead" serie is the future of adventure gaming, with atmospheric graphics, deep characters and convoluted storylines. However gameplay must be a part of it to really hit the spot, with real puzzles to solve.As it stand The Walking Dead is dangerously close to be an interactive story with different endings, nothing wrong with this kind of games especially when it's well done like this one, but I really think it could be more with some added gameplay especially in the puzzle section. With a little luck Telltales will deliver something like that soon, and we might just experience a new golden age in the adventure game scene...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												With The Walking Dead, Telltale have brought their signature gameplay style and aesthetic to a new level. While their previous efforts often stumbled in the story compartment, The Walking Dead is one of the best stories ever told in gaming and is worth your time and money, even at full price.The aesthetic the game resembles the comic it is based on, with dark outlines on everything and an overall cartoony style. The tone of the game is quite dark, but the aesthetic somehow fits regardless.The gameplay is based on a lot of simple puzzle solving, as well as quick time events and decision making. The conversation system is robust and offers several options for you to pursue in any conversation, and they affect the game in a small way. There are major decisions you have to make throughout the five episodes that will affect your story. It's no Mass Effect, but the choices you make still matter and will affect which characters live, and which characters die a horrible painful death.Gametime is about 12 hours with almost no filler (unless you get stuck on a puzzle).I recommend this game wholeheartedly, even if you were not a fan of Telltale's previous work. Haven't played the 400 Days DLC yet.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												If I had to describe The Walking Dead in one word I would say "Brutal". While this sounds like a criticism it is anything but. It's brutal, raw, and unbelievably good, but more on this later. The pacing, with incredibly tense moments (the truly amazing thing is that there are probably more tense dialog exchanges then action moments) juxtaposed with gut wrenching loss and tender hopeful moments, is masterful. The fact that critical decisions must be made (or not made) quickly works terrifically and is completely immersive. On a whole the conversation system is one of the better ones out there. Almost always you can tell from the prompt the content AND tone of the response which most systems fail to do. The characters are believable, varied, and deep but there were a couple times you could see your previous interactions with the person causing some seemingly out of character moments. Overall the mechanics and graphics, combined with a minimal but very effective soundtrack, are superb. Now about the feelies...While I don't want to get into what is and isn't a game, this most certainly is a game but the goals are just different then you may be used to. There are no points, there is no winning. This is the mindset you need to be in when going into this game. If you are unwilling to let your guard down, unwilling to feel, unwilling to actually immerse yourself in the story and live with your choices then you will walk away disappointed. This game is really a pure RPG. It doesn't need all the typical mechanics because that's not what defines a role playing game. I can not emphasize enough how much you can get out of this game if you are willing to lose yourself in it and make the decisions that feel right in your gut and heart, not the ones you think will give you a better ending. Once those decisions are made you need to live with them. You will second guess them, you will wonder if things would have turned out differently, and you most likely will come to regret something you did or said. That is part of why I led with the word "brutal". There are hard, nearly impossible, decisions that you have to make and live with in mere seconds. If you play this game and don't strongly feel at least some emotions, if it doesn't wear you down and weigh on your thoughts, you are not tough, you are not cool. You are short changing yourself. You are missing an opportunity to learn about yourself. As gamers we are constantly told our hobby is mindless entertainment, with little or no redeeming value. The Walking Dead is ready to prove that wrong, if you'll just let it.--- 400 Days DLC---400 Days is not meant to be the total emotional wringer that Season 1 was. It isn't trying to draw you in deep to a single character and experience. As such it won't have the same impact as Season 1 but that's fine because it wasn't supposed to. I think the problem is calling it Season 1 DLC when in reality its more of a bridge between seasons. You play 5 different, but intertwined, stories that introduces characters you are likely to meet and maybe play as in Season 2.Really the impact will just be delayed. When you're playing Season 2 and you know from experience a characters back story it gives a lot more weight to their existence, or lack their of. In Season 1 some of the early deaths didn't have a big emotional impact because we knew nothing about the character. If you play 400 Days that will change in Season 2. An early loss of one of these characters will carry some weight since you'll feel like you know them and will have formed an opinion of them. That being said there are still a couple of of those signature Walking Dead moments, showing how good Tell Tale is at this since they were able to set them up in only 15-20 minutes.If you are planning on playing Season 2 then I highly recommend 400 Days. It will wet your appetite for Season 2 and and should make it even more enjoyable, that brutal, visceral Walking Dead enjoyability.

												The Walking Dead has one of those universes where anything can happen and the possiblies are endless. I loved palying as Lee and protecting Clem as we fight The Undead...and The Living. The season was great even though I knew what happen 2 years before I bought the game. The stories that reminded me of the stories and conflicts in the show and comics are similar. The choices in this game aren't hard once you have an idea about it, but living with your choice can change you. I also like how you grew with the characters like Lee and Carley (If you chose to save Carley). I also liked the easter egg like a truck that says "♥♥♥♥♥♥Happens"; like Rick Grimes says in The Walking Dead TV Show Season 4 (Spoilers) when he uses a machete and kills Thomas in self defense. Other things like the comic book appearance of Glenn and Hershel...not the show but comic versions. (The game is connected with the comics and novels, not the show) Well anyways I liked this game and I recommend this to any TWD fan.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2013
												When I heard people/editorials praising this game and how "emotional" and "attatched" you get to the characters I thought to myself "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, no f'ing way."This was because Video games as a medium has failed to show me any emotional aspects in the past. I've had games where i felt bad for some characters, but for the first time I felt myself actually discovering/getting to know/care about fictional characters. I wanted to choose decisions which would benefit the characters. Every pivotal dialouge choice was so pain stakingly difficult as there usually was no exact "benefit everyone!" answer. Although the game is nothing much than an "interactive" movie, your decions ultimately do matter as they change some dialouge choices and who lives/dies. And to confess yes i did shed some MANLY TEARS in the last chapter. God damn. The game will really catch you by surprise, and shock you at how effective it is at making you immersed in its world. You won't notice at first ,but when the twists and turns jump out (and the game does this fast, even in the very first episode things go to♥♥♥♥♥♥ you'll really start to realize that you do care for what happens to the people inside the game.It's worth the price of  full admission to experience one of the finest games ever to be concocted last year. If  it's on sale it's a must have.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2012
												I was not by any means a Walking Dead fan until I played these games. I tried watching the TV series and I couldn't get in to them. Mainly because I was tired of the whole zombie smash kill apocalypse thing, and I never thought any other zombie experience would be able to captivate me. Then I stumbled upon The Walking Dead Game. This game is a story telling masterpiece with writing on par with the likes of Metal Gear Solid. It is most likely the best game I've played in 2012 and I have already named it my game of the year. It has very interesting characters that you'll care about and twists and turns you'll never see. From Clementine a lone little girl you begin to care for to Lee the mystery of a man you begin to play. It is a thrillride with the backdrop of the zombie apocalypse, and this time around the zombies took a backseat to the characters. It is an entirely different perspective of a would be zombie apocalypse and I HIGHLY recommend you do your self a favor and play this wonderful game. This game isn't about zombies, it is about a touching story of people and their will and spirit to live and survive while fighting to maintain their humanity. This game will break you emotionally, but it is such a beautiful and touching experience that I'm thankful to have been able to play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												The Walking Dead I a spin off game of the Walking Dead Series originally created by Robert Kirkman. This game was created by TellTale Games, and is just another amazing game to add to their repertoire.Gameplay:  You play either as Lee, (the main character), or as Clementine, as you move through the game. As Lee, your main goal throughout the game is to ensure the safety of Clementine, the little girl you meet near the beginning. The choices that you make directly affect what kind of relationship your character has with Clementine, as well as all the other characters in the game. The movements and controls are really smooth, throughout the entire game. It was not an overly challenging game, so even inexperienced gamers will have a relatively easy playthrough. Graphics:The graphics for this game were incredible. Everything looked almost too real to believe it came from a game. You can easily just stop and stare at the landscape around you. Jaw-dropping is the word I used the first time I had the chance to really get into the game.Audio:The voice acting was phenomenal. They really did an amazing job making the emotions really come alive. The music also complimented the atmosphere the game was trying to accomplish.Storyline:The follows the experiences of Lee and Clementine as they move through the apocalyptic zombie-ridden world. As you proceed through the game, the relationship between Lee and Clem gets more pronounced. Even though they are not related, they act as though they are. I felt like Lee took on the role of 'Uncle.' They are basically inseperable and Lee is more than the main reason why Clementine made it to the end. Her taught her everything he possibly could to help her survive.This game blew me away. I loved everything about it. From the unbelievable graphics to the voice actors and the storyline itself, everything wrapped together made for a truly amazing game. I was highly invested emotionally invested in the characters, and the tears at the end made it all seem that much more real. I would highly recommend this game to anyone and everyone!!

content:
Posted: November 20, 2013
												Definately a great immersive experience, but should be considered an interactive, visual novel. It has a great atmosphere, a strong narative and contains characters that express their feelings and opinions that produce and environment that is both believable and realistic.Although an unusual art-style, the game's artwork is unique and exhibits a sketch drawing style that is similar to the original walking dead comics.This 5 episode series introduces tough choices and experiences which can alter the storyline depending on your choice, giving awesome replayability, drama and action. Although the conclusion never changes depending on your choices, just being able to voice your opinion and communicate with the characters is more than enough to satisfy the player. The first episode might be mediocre, but it does develop and interesting events occur. Rating: 9/10 Although the gameplay elements are limited, this is still a great time-consuming story to enjoy and experience wether you are up for the price and the appocalyptic and eerie atmosphere. I couldn't recommend this game more.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												This is one of the best adventure / drama games to have come out in quite a long time.  You play as "Lee" a likable protagonist with a questionable background.   You are thrown head-first into the world of "The Walking Dead" from the comics and TV shows.As you progress you will come across the same locations and characters that Rick does in the comics, yet at different times than Rick.  The decisions you make in each chapter carry forward so they have true consequence.   How do you decide who will live or who will die?   Think quickly or you'll all be overrun.I would give it a solid 91% on the Yeti scale of greatness.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												    I picked this game up after hearing a lot about it during a summer sale and never really got around the actually playing until my SO, who watched the first season of the TV show, questioned me about it on my desktop.     I knew beforehand what type of game I was in for, and decided to invite my significant other to play along with me, thinking it would be an easy game to introduce her into the part of the video game world that WASN'T Mario Kart.    This is the perfect game for this situation. Got a friend or significant other you want to play a game with, and one or both of you are new to games? This is right up your alley. The game plays like more of a interactive movie. The controls are (for the most part) easy to understand, and the plot is very inticing, and the characters are what make this game so perfect. You wont find a single character (except for one, i've heard) that crosses into another part of The Walking Dead universe, and this game requires no previous knowledge of the series.     Seriously, pick up this game, play it with a friend or SO and you'll experience a variety of emotions with eachother. You'll have your own inside jokes about the quarks of the game, and you can open up an entire relationship with this person and future games of this kind. This is the perfect social game.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												I absolutely loved this game. I was uncertain at first because I tend to stick with what I'm already used to. Before I played The Walking Dead: Season One, I'd never played a TellTale game but I adored it. I was drawn to the game because I'm a huge fan of the television series. I haven't delved into the comics much because I know the stories don't match up, so I'm waiting for the show to finish before I start reading the comic again. The game gave me a different set of characters to worry about. I quickly grew attached to them and even grew a fondness for Clementine, the little girl that Lee takes care of. The story was awesome. Lots of twists and turns, much like the television show.The graphics were different than what I'd seen in games before. It's similar to Borderlands, which gives it a very comicbook feel to it. It definitely suits the game. The gameplay was also something that was foreign to me before playing it. I'd never experienced the way the character has to move. It's not like other games, but it's something I got used to quickly.Because of how much I loved this game, I also purchased TellTale's The Walking Dead: Season Two and Game of Thrones.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I'll start by saying this is one of very few games that's reduced me to tears and on numerous occasions, well done Telltale.The Walking Dead is an emotional rollercoaster that I found difficult to put down, proving that gameplay isn't what makes a videogame great. Each character has their own personality and motives, so no two characters are the same, and ultimately prevoke different emotions out of you, the player,I love the way the story is tailored to you, meaning that it's very rare for two people to have the outcome. Here's the basic outline of the story, you play as a convicted killer called Lee Everett and when you crash on the way to the police station you meet a young girl named Clementine and Lee must do everything he can to survive and protect herSo to conclude I'd like to say this game has one of the best stories going and if you're looking for a compelling story then look no further. But if you're in it for the gameplay or high end graphics, move on, The Walking Dead is all about the story, which will get you reaching for the tissues (not in that way to dirty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥).9/10 would bang again!

content:
Posted: June 21, 2013
												The Walking Dead is more of a character and choice driven interactive adventure game, such as Heavy Rain, over a puzzle driven adventure game like Monkey Island.  This means that the game is extremely easy but it's still a very satisfying experience.  I would argue that the characters and overall story contained within these episodes are better than most of the material on the TV show.  It is certainly much more effective in the development of the characters and for forcing an emotional connection to the various situations.  It isn't challenging but it's never boring and you are always eager to see where the story will go.  I was rooting for the characters and I think that shows that it is successful as a story driven title.  Definitely try this if you like The Walking Dead TV show or graphic novels, as well as titles such as Heavy Rain and even puzzle driven adventure titles.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												Just bought this game on special offer earlier this week, and I can't complain. I know I haven't completed the game yet (in fact I've only just finished Episode 2), but I feel ready to give my opinion despite the fact I'm not finished playing it.So... for starters, this game is not for everyone. There's not much "gameplay" if you get my point, as in that there isn't heavy action mouse-and-keyboard input from the player, and it's a game you really play for the story. At this point you'd be typically thinking it's like a "movie game" due to being a low-action game that takes on a very cinematic style (including TV style intros and outros joining each episode), but it's not like that at all. The game actually requires a lot of skill, in the sense that your decision could get you killed at any moment.The game forces the player to make decisions (in terms of both words and actions) in serious situations, all within an apocalyptic storyline. There are also many people in the game, who can be affected by your decisions. So, in other words, there are pretty much relationships in this game. My favourite thing about this game is that you can make Lee (the main character) have a similar personality to yourself, something that can't be achieved in a movie, but has been achieved in a video game. The story manages to be easy to understand, while maintaining its serious nature.The only people I would not recommend this game to is people who are generally disinterested in the storyline when playing through a video game, and want a lot of action and fewer cutscenes. For anyone who cares about the story will be surprised by the originality, and there will be enough gameplay to satisfy. Fantastic game in all respects.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												The Walking Dead: Season 1 is simply a masterpiece of video game story telling.  I salute Telltale for their work and I am looking forward/excited to explore season 2.  I have to admit that this game was an emotional journey that impacted me a lot in the last couple of weeks.  These characters, the decisions they had to make, the consequences they had to live with, all these elements made me genuinely care for what would happen to them.  Pros:+ Characters that we care for and get attached to (or love to hate!)+ Clementine & Lee+ Voice actors are doing an amazing job at humanizing these characters+ Dialogue system and quick decision time+ Creates a true emotional involvment from the player+ Relationship between the members of the group+ Easy gameplay that serves a robust scenario first and foremost+ Different decisions leading to different paths (though the overall story line stays the same)Cons:- Gameplay could have been more developped/fleshed- Some slow/uninspired moments- Technically not a revolution....  Noentheless, I liked the cell shedding style.Verdict: A+

The decisions you make in each chapter carry forward so they have true consequence.   How do you decide who will live or who will die?   Think quickly or you'll all be overrun.I would give it a solid 91% on the Yeti scale of greatness.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												This is by far the best game I have ever played, in terms of gameplay and storyline depth. Every decision counts, everything has a knock on effect. Every action you take influences another. I kept on thinking at points, "What if I'd done it different?" "What if I had chosen to do this another way? Would it have played out differently?". This game is not just about killing zombies. Not even close. It goes into detail about the characters, the stories. Some stories stay with you for a lifetime, this one - for me - certainly will. After playing Walking Dead Survival Instinct, I was disapponted. After playing this, I think it is capable of becoming a film. The storyline is gripping, dynamic, unique but most importantly ( like some other games ) this game makes you care about the characters. It makes you care what happens. It makes you think about how you choose to resolve situations will impact everyone else. How it will impact the story.I won't insult this game by giving it a rating out of ten. It deserves better.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												           A great survivor point and click adventure that does the Walking Dead license great justice.The Walking Dead excels in its dialogue.  Your decisions will tailor the way the game turns out. . The survival of your group members hinges on making the right choices in a post apocalyptic world.  Choices you make effect the people you travel with the most. After a couple of episodes group members were reacting to me completely differently then how they would react to another friend who had advanced the same length in the story.  There are big events that cannot be avoided no matter what choices you make however as the developers progess the story.         The game play is fun and there is action sprinkled in to the dialogue as there should be with a post apoclyptic game. The action is jarring and requires a quick reaction that takes a little getting used to. I had to die a couple of times during the first couple of events to get the hang of it and play smoothly. Running from and killing walkers was very satisfying. The story is fun and interesting. I found myself wanting to get to learn about the people I was travelling with and became quickly attached to the characters. If you want a thrilling story with zombies that has choices with weight behind them then I strongly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												I finally made it through this game, after stopping a couple times at some parts where it got a bit too messed up for me. But honestly, what more could you ask for a game about a post-apocaliptic world where you have to make hard choices about life and death and other serious matters? This is also the game that single-handedly resurected the point and click adventure, and changed it from a genre dominated by humor filled quirky puzzle games, to more of a five episode interactive television miniseries type thing. "Winning" or "Losing" isn't really an issue in this game, the fun is to make hard choices and then see how those choices influence the story in the future, guiding the story the way you want. I went back and played the first two episodes, and your choices really influence the direction of the story, in a general kind of way. I also really really enjoyed the 400 days DLC, which was five stories about 30 minutes each that really didn't get bogged down in "I can't believe you!" yelling matches that seemed to pop up frequently in the main game.This game is absolutely worth your time and money. It's about 2 hours for each episode, and 5 episodes and a DLC, so you should get about 12 hours out of it. You might want to take a break between episodes, as they can hit pretty hard emotionally. Which, like I said before, is what you want! Play it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2012
												This game surprised me, as I didn't expect much, but I got so much from it. The Walking Dead is about zombies, nothing too original there and there is even a TV show carrying the same name, although the events there and in this game are not the same. Instead you follow a differerent group of people and how they cope with the world being overrun by hungry zombies at every corner, not to mention people who may use or kill you for their own gain. It is a rough setting and this game portrays it very well in every gruesome detail. The game plays like an adventure game added with some timed choices and quick time events. It sounds simply and it is, but combined with a great story it turns it into a great game. It is the choices you make which carries the game, and every choice can have a great impact of what happens later on or in the next scene. This also means the game has replay value if you want to see what each choice does. I know zombies is overused these days, but the game isn't that much about zombies but more about people facing a new and unforgiving reality. It is truly a great game you will get a lot of enjoyment from if you're into story driven games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												The Walking Dead puts you in the shoes of a character in a zombie apocalypse, puts a little girl in your care, and then asks you what you would do to survive and protect her. Coupled with good storytelling, good voice acting and nice art based on the comic book series, this game becomes a really good and even really emotional experience.Telltale has developed a somewhat stock gameplay mechanic of mostly dialogue sequences that offer you four responses (or silence) and give you a limited time to choose these. Usually these choices will influence either one character's view of you, and often they force you to pick sides beteen two characters. In most of their games I find this system kind of frustrating, as the loyalty choices often feel very forced and transparent.For this game, though, it's perfect - unlike in many other games, your character, Lee, doesn't yet know any of the people he meets. It's a dangerous world where zombies are always near and survival depends on who you trust and who you don't. That perfectly justifies making quick decisions on who to be friendly to and who to regard with suspicion, and that you have a time limit of only seconds to make that choice in.A lot of games now have a simple good/evil/neutral decision system, but the scenario of this game creates an interesting alternative where you're basing your decisions on what's best for survival of yourself, your little girl and possibly the rest of the group. Whereas in most games I'm all about being the noble hero, here I found myself choosing to abandon a character to die because I felt my group stood a better chance of survival without him. That felt kind of messed up.The Walking Dead will get under your skin and make you feel good and bad, if you let it. I found it one of the most engaging and rewarding game experiences I've had in my life.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Having come from a TV series binge of The Walking Dead, I decided that I should give the game sat in my library a go having heard good things about it. Initially my expectations were set in for some kind of third person strategic shooter horror sing-along.What The Walking Dead actually does is drop you in to the control of convicted murderer Lee, determined to protect a young girl named Clementine, and gives you control and freedom to explore like an old point and click game. Learn more by examining items and world objects or talk to people for a better understanding of the situation at hand. It leaves out the old style puzzles, mostly walking you through logical steps rather than asking you to combine items and use them creatively. Action mostly consists of quick time event style button mashing and clicking when you need to fend off the zombie hordes or perform other dynamic actions.The game makes up for any misgivings you may have about its QTE-centric style by putting control of Lee's dialogue and decisions in your hands. Want to yell at Clementine for running off or take the softer approach? Who should you help during a panic event, or how should you deal with a games villain? You decide. Dialogue responses such as lies or support/criticism of other characters can be noted and used against you at a later date. The finale of the game actually rebuffs you for some of your decisions, really hitting home why you made them.The characters around you are well written and well voiced but don't get too attached as the zombies won't worry about chewing on your favourite NPC. Dialogue between Lee and Clementine can be very touching and you come to feel real responsibility for her. Other characters can befriend or mistrust you and the game at times made me respond less rationally than I thought I might in tense and dangerous situations. I know I felt bad about some of the things I said or did in front of Clementine. The music is also top notch and catches the mood just right.The games 5 chapters kept me entertained and the additional DLC was short but interesting and sets up Season 2 with its output.I never experienced a game breaking glitch or bug although there are some cosmetic features, such as zombies all shambling  in the same rhythm or characters occasionally juddering about, that you may notice. Some of the more hectic moments will lead you to miss less obvious action choices and make a large decisions you didn't know you were making, forcing you down a fork you tried to avoid.All in all I loved it and recommend it to those who like the TV show or a good story with zombies.TL:DRGreat interactive story with dialogue choice and critical decisions left to the player. Not a zombie shooter.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												The Walking Dead is bassed of a comic of Robert Kirkman's. The game tells the story of Lee (a convicted criminal) and Clementine (a young girl in the Apocalypse). Basing the story off of the two characters alone would not give the game justice. Unlike most games, Clementine isn't as annoying as you might think. Infact she is really humorous and you begin to have a connection with her as you progress. You meet other survivors such as, Glenn (for a short time) Lily, her father Larry, Kenny and his family, Doug, Carley, and a ton of other characters along the way. The character interaction is probably the best part about the game, as what you say will determine whether or not someone trusts you, or even likes you. It's not just about speech, as actions also determine whether or not if they like you or hate you. It's incredibly difficult to go on to explain why this game is so great without going into spoiler territory. The game is well worth the $25 dollars alone, but at the moment it's on sale for $6.30. TAKE THE DEAL. You will not be dissapointed!

content:
Posted: November 15, 2013
												What a strangely satisfyingly-sickening experience.  There are flaws in the gameplay and occasionally I felt that I didn't have enough of an influence on the outcome or choice in the direction I took, but ultimately all of that paled before the superb storytelling and overall product.  The presentation through atmosphere, both cinematic and auditory, was excellent.For fans of The Walking Dead universe or zombie-lore in general, I couldn't recommend this more.  Buy it immediately if you have the cash or snatch it up on one of its sales.  It was an absolute steal when I purchased it at just over $6!If you're squemish in the least, tread carefully, for tough choices lay before you - decisions that often left me more disturbed than the gore required of any zombie product.Two thumbs WAY up... but only long enough to get the point across.  I wouldn't want them to be gnawed off.Cheers!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2012
												♥♥♥♥ing. Amazing.Alright, so to lay it out for you...On the company and their style:  A lot of people have been giving Telltale flack after how Jurassic Park was so heavily Quick-Time-Event oriented.  Understandably so.  Let me start off by clearing this up - This game is NOT QTE ORIENTED!  At all!  The closest it has is a few moments when you need to make a decision under pressure - if you don't decide fast enough it just makes something else happen.  Very neat aspect!On the Walking Dead IP and it's use here:   This is NOT based off the Television show.  That has NOTHING to do with this game.  This is set in the COMIC world with COMIC art style.   HOWEVER, it's a story that hasn't been told - focused on a character that we never knew.   That said, there are cameos and locations from the comics that are amazing to see as an avid reader.The game itself:   ♥♥♥♥ing. Awesome. Zombie. Game.  5/5.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												I highly recommend this game. To me it has one of the best plots of all video games i ever played.The Story and the plot are .. just great.  Never saw something this sad and yet, you want to get going and going. Death always lies right around the corner and you really have to fear that something bad could happen and you still want to know what will happen next. The developers made a really good job. I think this game could be something even for people that despise the zombie genre in general, because it isn't so much about the Zombies but more about the charactrs and the drama.The characters are all great. The story itself is about Clementine a 8 year old girl that is alone in a world full of Zombies. You play as Lee. A guy who was about to go to jail for murder, but doesn't get there..... Don#t want to spoil that much, but in the end you meet Clementine and Lee tries to protect her. Especially that is what makes the plot and story so great. At least to me, it made me really want to protect that little girl. You really start to care for her and so does lee. The dynamics between these two are awesome. The other characters are very well written as well. Evey character you meet has a unique personality and yet, it isn't easy to figure them all completely out. The graphics are "unique". It is more a comic look. Not the preference of everybody, but it fits this dark plot quite well. Of course they are a bit outdated, but the comic style makes it look younger than it really is.The mechanics are rudmentary. You actually use 4 keys and the mouse. That its about it. In the end it is more like a tv show than a game. Which isn't really bad, because of the story and the characters. You actually just walk around and solve some puzzles. You talk to people and this way keep the plot going. Here and there you have to shoot zombies or have to click something in a short period of time. Those "minigames" felt not overdone and mixed the game a bit up. Yes the game could give you more controls over Lee, but in the end it is about the characters and story and not the game mechanics. There aren't any bugs i noticed. Isn't that hard to create bugs anyway. Since every scene and possible outcome is scripted anyway.If i would have one wish, i would like to see that your choices do matter a bit more. Yes your coices matter quite a lot for the ongoing plot. Who do you side with, who do you distrust, but a bit more impact wouldn't have hurt.Anyway, i recommend this game to anyone who has the money and seeks a sad, but yet powerful story with great characters and, of course, zombies :)

												It was about half a year ago that I first played this game, and at the time it didn't really grab my attention all that much. I would have to say that the first part of the first episode (the only one I had played at that point), is not exactly representative of the game as a whole; it gets a whole lot better. Recently I acquired a PC that could actually play this game (my first foray into the game being on an xbox 360). and I picked up the game for 75% off during a Steam Sale. And I have to say, it is one of the better games I have ever bought.Playing through this game is an incredible experience. It continues to be as such on consecutive playthroughs, but nothing can compare to that first time. The choices you have to make have an incredible impact, and can drastically change how large portions of the game play out.In the end, if you're a fan of the Walking Dead TV show, but even more so if you are a fan of the comic books, then you should definitely pick this up. It is an experience that will change you forever, and I could not more highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2013
												If you want a game where you make choices that impact the narrative in a way beyond "you get +5 blue points and -5 red points and now you can use blue dialogue options", then you want The Walking Dead. Don't get me wrong- the major story milestones are set in stone.  But everything around them can change pretty dramatically, in terms of character behaviors, interactions, and some very impactful decisions.  You'll hit the big moments everyone else hits, but the whole journey will be unique to you and your decisions.The Walking Dead is an important game for the future of interactive narratives in mainstream titles, and you should play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												When you first play the game, the one thing that hits you is the art style; Designed around the illustrations of The Walking Dead comics with a completely new cast of characters. The game is solely based on the decisions of the player, from things to say; to pivotal plot points, the game gives you a variety of options to choose from and a limited time to do so. Throughout the game you can get very attached to the characters, one minute everything's fine, the next you're sent into shock as something may have gone horribly wrong. This is what the game does well and builds its story around this alongside the problems and drama you will face. This interesting point and click adventure asks the player to scavenge and be creative with how they handle situations;  using a pillow to silence a gun or even distracting zombies with TVs on display in a store. Also the game has a system where each character will remember your actions and recall them later on in the story; this can be when you don't take sides with someone or when you don't agree with their ideas. This can lead to characters holding grudges or characters willing to back you up.It's episodic format what originally helped the pacing of the game; each ending on a different note that will cause you to buy the next episode to continue those compelling moments of the story much like when you read the hardback comics. Although since all the episodes are out, you can buy all of them together and play through the them all. Honestly the story is what I like about the game the most; this is because at the end you make a choice that will cause you sadness either way; even when Lee is bitten there is no escape from his fate. Even after you've finished playing you will remember the game for it's strong characters, some have which may have died and some may have survived.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												When I began "The Walking Dead", I honestly did not know what to expect. The only thing I knew about it before-hand was that it has gotten worldwide critical acclaim and that it was sort of like a point-and-click kind of game, which I'm not too big of a fan of. When I started playing it, however, my thoughts started to change. By the time I had completed episode 1, I was eager to beat the game just to find out what happens. Surprisingly, the game isn't too heavy on gameplay. Instead, the story is what drives the game forward. I was always excited to play the game so I could find out what would happen to the characters. The game has a ton of drama and suspence to spice up the plot, which is needed since the plot is what the game relies on. The fact that the game changes depending on the choices you make is (to me) one of the biggest and greatest features of the game, and it adds a lot of replay value.By the end of the story (which isn't terribly long, maybe 12 hours or so), I had gotten so emotionally attatched to the characters, which made the ending one of the saddest endings I have ever witnessed in a game. It seriously made me teary-eyed. So, in conclusion, "The Walking Dead" isn't heavy on gameplay, but that's not really what the game's supposed to be about, and you just have to adapt to it. It's the story that makes it incredible, especially the fact that it changes depending on the choices you make.9/10, would recommend to anybody who would like a good story or fans of the TV show/comic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												I went into The Walking Dead with few expectations. I was only vaguely familiar with the comic's existence. I believe the show had at least started, but what little I'd seen of it bored me. I wasn't even particularly familiar with Telltale Games at the time, outside of knowing they handled newer takes on the Monkey Island and Sam & Max properties. That was it. And now, I can easily say The Walking Dead remains one of, if not, their best adventure game, even with more of the same world and visits to other worlds adopting the choices-with-consequence model The Walking Dead established.Right off the bat, The Walking Dead manages to establish its setting at a breakneck pace without being confusing or unclear. You're in Georgia. You're in trouble. Then suddenly, you -and- Georgia, and the whole world for that matter, are in a whole lot more trouble than anyone bargained for. The core cast gets established fairly quickly, then the pace begins to ease up a bit to give you time to get comfortable with your new avatar and his associates. Lee, the one left to rot. Clementine, the one left behind. Kenny, the one left to act. And there are plenty of supporting characters, all distinct, many memorable, helping hold up these eventual pillars of the story as well.One point of contrast between how conversations and action sequences is handled in The Walking Dead really struck me: it's the little things, like what you choose to say or whom you choose to say it to, that have the longest-running impact and the greatest effect on your overal experience of the game, and in most cases, there's no undo. Meanwhile, coming back from failure during a quick-time-event, which typically ends in fatality, is almost instant, and is the closest thing to "fixing" any of your actions you get a chance to do. This really helps emphasize the importance of the characters and their interaction over any sort of outside actors or circumstances that is the core of the game on the whole.If you decide to play through The Walking Dead, you're going to cry. You're going to yell, too, and smile. You'll love some characters, you'll hate others. And the best thing is? It's unlikely the moments and people that fit those lists for you will match up exactly with anyone else. Even if you're not a fan of the other Walking Dead media properties, you owe it to yourself to play this game.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												After playing through this season twice (once on 360, once on Steam), I can definitely say without a doubt in my mind that this is one of the best, most emotionally compelling story-based games out there. If you want a ride of emotions, buy this game. The gameplay is sparse, but that's not what the game is about. The actual gameplay is based on you (Lee) making decisions that affect you and your whole party, leading to friends, enemies, conflict, and lots of death. Overall, the first playthrough is about 8 hours long and every playthrough afterwards is about 6 hours since you know what you want to do. If you haven't played this game and love a good story, buy it now, or wait for a sale. It typically goes for 75% off and it is more than worth it at that discount. Do yourself a favor and buy this game.

Posted: August 2, 2015
												The Walking Dead is an amazing game with an absolutely superb story that will certainly trigger an emotional response on the player.It forces the player to make tough decisions, the characters and voice acting are superb  and it's without any doubt, one of the best narrative and storytelling videogames, not only in recent years, but in videogame history.If I had to rate this game, I would give it 10/10 for sure, and I certainly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												"The Walking Dead" is, by far, the best choose your own adventure style game that I have played since "Heavy Rain" was released. This comparison is fairly accurate, as both games allow the player to make major decisions that completely change the course of events in the narrative. Who lives and dies? That's up to the player. Who gets to join your group? Again, a choice which is left largely up to the player. It's worth noting that, while many key decisions in the game are left up to the player, no decision is without consequences. The game does a great job of making you feel like your choices are important, because they are.Additionally, "The Walking Dead" tells a fantastic story! Its the kind of story that keeps you going forward to find out what happens next. The writers have done a great job of making you feel for every character you meet. You'll hate some, love others, even be annoyed by a select few. However, the choice of how you react to them and deal with them is largely up to you, the player. I can not stress enough how much I enjoyed the storyline and the personalities which populated it. The only thing that may put a few people off is the scare factor. The game is by no means a horror movie, but it does have it's share of jump scares and the overall tone of the game is one of danger around every corner. Although, if you are looking into a zombie game, you're probably fine with that. The game holds about the same scare factor as "Resident Evil" on the Playstation 1, but with far better storyline. Additionally, these scenes all make sense within the narrative and don't feel like a cheap scare tactic. If you have ever seen "The Walking Dead" television series, you should know what I'm referring to. The game can also be a very dark in certain spots, as it deals with desperate people trying to survive. However, the player is allowed to take the moral highroad in nearly all situations if they so desire.Overall, "The Walking Dead" is a fantastic gaming experiance! If you find yourself on the fence about playing this game, play it!  10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2013
												Every positive thing you've heard about this game is accurate. Telltale has really put something special together with this game. The writing is incredible, the direction is out of this world, and the impact that your choices have is anything but superficial. While it's definitely more movie than game, it's at least an entertaining movie, and you're very likely to be too swept up in the branching plot paths to care. Well worth the purchase, even at full price.
